A beautiful game. Playthrough time is fairly short, took me just over 7 hours (though I didn't 100% it) but I think it's absolutely worth your time.

I absolutely loved this game to death, I was really shocked with how my laptop handled it (Asus tuf gaming A17 if youre wondering) I am so sad i finished it so fast, I finished it within two days of playing. Definitely couldve finished sooner if i played non stop but it only took me 6 hours to beat the game (i didnt do really any side quests) I think including side quests the game is 10 hours long
Do you enjoy cats? Do you want to become a cat? Well you can!
10 meow meow out of 10.

It would be hard to criticize this game since it is neither difficult nor offensive in any way.  It is quite brief, however.  I finished it in nine hours of play time.  It was definitely a fun experience and there are some touching moments in the story.  The best part of the game is the unique perspective of the player character, that of the lost cat finding his way back home.  The level design and art direction are quite nice and there are plenty of moments that contain action sequences that can be challenging.  I am playing on a PC with a mouse and keypad controller and the two peripherals worked well in the game, a console game controller is not necessary to play the game.  For me, this was an enjoyable alternative to the sprawling RPGs and immersive sims that I normally play.
great game...B to meow

i recommend it for the story 


i like the games story i like the fact that your a cat and the robots

what i dont like:

the zurks  it's not that they are hard its that they are a okay attempt at making a challenging part the levels which contain them are kind of and if i lower the resolution to 2nd to lowest  it's easy to avoid. and i font really feel like a ct playing this game

my computer isn't strong enough for it to run on high resolution  and no i'm not a competitive player 

i have watched full game play and it doesn't impress me  please don't try and say anything stupid like "oh you have to play it more to have fun" 


i'm still going to play it because of the robots, and the story and even then the zurks are still a decent amount of fun
 

 not worth the $30 price tag

A must for every cat lover

Fantastic game. All the obvious cat perfection aside, genuinely a great little puzzle/adventure game. Story and levels are relatively short and linear so it allows them to craft some really spectacular and deeply touching moments. Gameplay and puzzles are basic as well but are very solid; nothing overstays its welcome and should be doable for any gaming skill level. Graphics are absolutely gorgeous especially for a smaller studio. The attention to detail in every aspect of this game really shines. And if you already love cats you'll love this game regardless.
amazing

Waited a lot of time to play this game and it found my expectations perfectly. Beautiful, amazing 8 hours of gameplay that will leave you sobbing. Couldn't take my eyes away from the monitor, graphics are absolutely breath-taking. Definitely must-play for a cats lovers and people that like well made plots.
Magnificent! Master piece

Stray is a beautiful game. I absolutely love the story, characters, locations, scenery, ambiance, music, graphics, game mechanics and of course, the orange cat itself. I wish we got more games like this. The old days of fun and quick story driven AA games are not gone, but they aren't as plenty as they should be. Stray may be one of my favorite games in this category, and I loved every minute of it. I have nothing bad to say, except there were a couple bugs where I had to reload because the characters or world did not progress to their correct places, Nothing major, but want to note it. I do wish the mechanics were a bit more fleshed out, as it seems like auto jumping, but the game did it so well, I don't really care anymore about that. This is a beautiful game and I wish we got more games like this. Everyone has to play this game, and I hope you all do.

A really great game. I enjoyed the story and mystery alongside playing a cat.

this game has become one of my favorite games. from the small details like the paw prints from walking in paint, the decor in different rooms, to the unique design of every robot, just makes this game 10 times better than what it wouldve been. the NPCs all have a different personality and you cannot find two identical robots. although the playtime was short compared to other story games, the game is full of story in every chapter. personally, i was always fond of the cyberpunk theme and my heart has a special place for this game. even on the lowest graphics this game does not fail to look absolutely stunning. this game really reached higher than my expectations and i do not regret buying this game. meow asf

Great game, especially if you love cats. Very atmospheric. The puzzles were the perfect difficulty.  I could figure them out on  my own, but they weren't trivial. The stealth parts were tense and scary. 
My only complaint is the game is inconsistent with warning when you are about to leave a zone and not be able to return, so a couple times I wasn't able to go back and find all the memories.
Great game, unique! We love cats!

I'm honestly so mad I missed out on getting this game when it came out! It's such an amazing game with an amazing story and mechanics. The physics and the looks and everything about this game is so good! This game is definitely one of my all time favourites and I would 100% recommend for everyone to play it!

I loved this game so much it was so fun and different from most games. the graphics are stunning and the story line is so interesting. I actually cried at the end of this game thats how interested in the story i was.
...the way he leaps off of rooftops and always lands on four feet to face the camera before scratching at the nearby post is just full of the exaggerated cuteness of a kitty cat

I finished in 8.5 hours you can finish in 5 but it's so pretty and emotional and I think my favorite game I've played so far this year. I highly recommend it if you're really into lore and getting into the story, it's so worth it.
Fun puzzle game.  Nice for a quick break from the heavy strats I usually play.

(!) Stray is fantastic. Stray has done what many games canâ€™t do in terms of visuals, not only did BlueTwelve craft one of the most beautiful visually and atmospherically games out there, they were able to convey a lot of emotion through these environments and visuals. The story is emotional and although simple, very effective. The soundtrack composed by Yann van der Cruyssen is sentimental and thrilling. I have faced a few bugs during some of my playthroughs and also really wished that there were less dialogs and that more of the story would be told through the environment and how the characters interact within it, but this complaint is not enough to not make me not love this game. Thank you BlueTwelve Studio for this emotional and memorable game. 9/10
It is genuinely good, there are so many things to explore. The art style is very unique too. Got it recently. It is very fun searching for sheets for the musician.
10/10 quick easy fun cute. Cat goes Meow

In the game where you get to be a cat, you truly learn what it feels like to have humanity in a world that's suffering.
This game = cool, ending made me cry tho ;v;

As a lover of cats, robots and dystopian scifi stories, I enjoyed this game greatly. The robot characters with their personalities and funny dialogue and all the details around the Walled City were enhancing. The story where the dark truth was revealed little by little kept me playing even through the parts where the bit clumsy gameplay and lack of savepoints made me repeat the same part a bit too many times. Overall the game was not too difficult nor too easy, but if you are looking for a good action game this is probably not the best match. But if you are looking for a cool and interesting story, well built atmosphere and a game where you can jump around as a cat (and do other random cat like stuff like dropping mugs, destroying sofas and just sleeping on random pillows), this is definitely worth using the 10 to 15 hours it will take to finish the game.

Beautiful, creative, touching, and loads of fun! I loved so many things about it - the graphics, the story, characters, and world; being able to play comfortably with no HUD; how seamless and charming the tutorial was; the frequent and comic juxtaposition of very human elements with "I'm a cat, thank you very much"... the list can go on. 

I also want to mention how each moment of the game seemed to have designed with a lot of care and passion - the game mechanics, though relatively straightforward and not-too-challenging, never got old because each action section, along with its environment, was so uniquely and immersively designed.

Overall, a wonderful experience!
BRILLIANT GAME!!!
Be asshole cat

The world is atmospheric and beautiful, the story is compelling enough for me to care, the cat animations are really cute, the game wasn't too short or too long. Overall a well made cat adventure game in a dystopian environment. 10/10 would recommend.

Fun games with a great story, good writing and compelling graphics. Pretty short for a 30 dollar game, so I'm happy I got it discounted but it's still longer that a CoD campaign so no complaints.

I'd recommend getting it on sale, it's definitely an enjoyable experience.

It is an amazing game if you are able to sit down and play it, unlike me, I usually like more sandbox games then story games, or games with lore, or tasks, but this game just changed that around, the chapters are pretty short, I got it a while ago, I got to chapter 4 then stopped playing for a year.. I started playing it again and I am already at Chapter 10, all I am saying is, it is worth the money, it is also horrifying, in a good way, just wait until you get into certain chapters.
gato

Beautiful game in every way. Looks stunning, is bug free (in my experience), and runs buttery smooth (12700 & 3080).

Without spoiling the story, the robots exude a warm humanity lacking in many humans. The plot was intriguing, unique, and poignant. There is a beauty here that is rare in video games. The cuteness of your character is a welcome presense in a dark world. Playing a cat offers interesting gameplay elements that allow access to places denied to humans or human sized robots.

The pacing is brilliant with the story advancing often enough to remain engaging throughout, but without feeling rushed. This is primarily an experience about exploration, characters, and narrative, although it does sometimes offer some well justified moments of tension.

This feels like such a beautifully considered and well thought-through experience for mature minds. A gem of a game in a sea of unoriginal sequels and cheap thrills.
Cute, simple, interesting and generally a really good time.

One of my favorite games of all time. Charming, gorgeous to look at, with a good story and overall a fantastic adventure. Being a cat is cool and changes the way you explore and interact with the world in a big way, it's really well done.

It's really impressive how this was made by an indie studio. I'm hoping they make a sequel.

I can definitely see why this has won the amount of awards it has. The story is beautiful and while it wasn't as long or as open world as I expected, I would absolutely play this again. I'm hoping this has a 2nd installment, because this is DEFINITELY missing something in the end. If you're in a depressive state already, please re-consider playing this, because it will absolutely break your heart. I did find it a slight bit predictable, but not in a game-ruining way.

7/10. If it was full price it would be 5/10. It's definitely an interesting world and a unique cat experience. I just wish it was a good game as well. Also, it's too short even for the price. I'm definitely interested in a squeal though.

THE GOOD

- I can't think of another game that makes you feel as much like a cat as this game does

- The art direction and general world is outstanding. It always feels like a mystical adventure because of it's good atmosphere 

- The story is actually surprisingly decent. It's not Charles Dickens and it's stunted by it's short length, but it's fine.

- Dedicated meow button

THE MEH

- The Assassin's Creed style for parkour is, like Assassin's Creed, easy most of the time but frustrating when it doesn't work properly as there's no plan B. It worked most of the time for me, but occasionally I had to fiddle about to get where I wanted to.

THE BAD

- It's very short. One of the game's achievements states that you can complete it in 2 hours. It will probably take you more like 5-7, but that's still at least 10 hours shorter than I would like for this price.

- It's crying out for some RPG style quality of life improvements as it slightly leans into an RPG discovery style of play. Things like a quest menu, a quest pointer. different cat skins, a consistent currency, fast travel, etc. XP for doing things (like scratching stuff) could unlock some of these things.

- I would like to see more ways of interacting with the robots such as more dialogue options or using characters in more scenarios. Some of the robots feel 2D.

- More side quests please

- Could be more difficult or at least have the option of harder difficulties

- I would love to have the opportunity to use my claws to properly destroy things, but maybe for the cost that's a bit much to ask for

Stray is a game that does well at providing a cat-like experience contrasted with interesting visuals and urban environments, at the cost of obtuse narrative, game and level design.

The best thing about Stray is its cat-like movement and camera. They feel very well done with only the occasional unnecessarily jarring camera switches in isolated cases. It is fun just walking around in an environment being a cat. Unfortunately, this part of the experience is short lived as the game force-drags you through a lot of muddled scenery, with unclear and obtusely delivered objectives and design language that make you second guess where to go. It is a short game, and I had to consult a walkthrough multiple times because I was at a loss for what to do next.

The narrative is full of convoluted logic and magical realism that seems to have been born from the necessity of creating a framework for a game about a cat like experience. This unfortunately makes for both a less believable world and a worse overall experience. There's also a certain narrative dissonance implied by a cat somehow having a stake and intent to participate in a robot (but not really) rebellion. A real shame since it takes away from the simple elegance of the cat experience by forcing it to be in the center of some contrived plot that in the end doesn't serve the protagonist cat as a character whatsoever.

it may be worth talking about the environments as well. It is very well done, and in the best of cases provides an ample playground for being a cat. If the game had been more free form and without forcing the player to be dragged through the narrative, it would have been a great place to explore - especially through the eyes of a cat. Sadly, because of the narrative and level design, it is often the case that optional paths are shut down in favor of following the exact thoughts that the designer had in mind, which again contrasts heavily with the nature of a cat.

For the length of its gameplay and its various flaws, I can't recommend it at full price, but I'd say it's worth at a discount. For me, the standout experience was being a cat in the environment, and had that been the entire game without the narrative being shoehorned in, it would have been an excellent game.

The game was fun, but very on rails. It has a decent story, nothing crazy in-depth. I came to this from Outer Wilds and while Stray feels similar, it lacks in freedom and story richness that Outer Wilds has. I picked it up on sale for $20 and feel that is probably the high end for what you should pay. The total play time is 5 to 6 hours.

The game isâ€¦. Fine

Youâ€™re a cute hyper intelligent cat that falls into the sewers and tries to get out. The gameplay is a mishmash of platforming, puzzle solving, inventory style adventure gaming, and mild combat. Most of that gameplay is pretty restrictive since you canâ€™t platform or even without a button prompt. Every logic puzzle is just x->y->z (but at least it makes sense), and the mild combat is basically strafing and running which never gets complex. Really the gameplay is there to just support the story and the world building which was good. There's an initial mystery of whatâ€™s going on, why the [spoiler]robots[/spoiler] are where they are and whatâ€™s outside. That sense of discovery and meeting various [spoiler]robots[/spoiler] really characterizes them and makes you understand the city and how folks live. I think the ending was rushed a bit and the themes it was going for could have been better displayed in the first parts of the game but the world building was really good. Plus, the pacing of having tension separated by open areas to explore the world was welcomed. Also, the visuals and atmospheric music are really good and really help drive the anxiety/sadness in the game.

That being said, its super jank feeling and basic movement and camera movement feels rough. Itâ€™s super linear and the gameplay never gets past â€œgo forwardâ€. The plot kinda rushes and runs out of steam a bit by the end. The last city especially felt like more was planned with its gorgeous visuals but just kinda gave up. Overall, the game is fine and the cat is cute so get it on sale.

[h1] Such a purrfect, pawsome and meowrable journey [/h1]

Iâ€™d kept an eye on Stray for some time, unsure whether or not a horror lover like me should invest in this semi-open world, neon-colored and cyberpunk-themed cat game. But when it was released with everyone being so hyped about it, I had no other choice but join the community. And I have zero regrets.

Visually, Stray is like eye candy; the vibrant cityscapes are so beautiful that youâ€™ll find yourself lost in the details. Owing to an excellent audio, cat-chy tunes and exploration-heavy game play, youâ€™ll get immersed in a bleak future where robots live like humans in an underground city, perfected with a few simple puzzles and survival sequences to keep things interesting. Nevertheless, Stray is nothing too demanding for an overall relaxing experience. The narrative putting a heavy emphasis on non-verbal cues, I like how simply and understandably social and environmental issues are presented in a game that looks more superficial and unimpactful than it actually is.

If you like cats, you should buy this - itâ€™s a good enough reason. Think about it: you can meow, scratch, climb, sleep, make a mess, nuzzle and do cute cat things as an adorable little furball that is, in my humble opinion, a well-animated representation of a humanized real-life cat. Thereâ€™s nothing better than getting to be a small four-legged creature in a large and curious world, right?

I can't praise Stray enough! This game is an absolute gem that exceeded all my expectations. From the moment I stepped into its beautifully crafted world, I was captivated by the stunning visuals and immersive atmosphere. The gameplay mechanics are innovative and refreshing, allowing you to navigate the bustling city streets with ease.

But what truly sets Stray apart is its heartwarming narrative. As a lost cat, you embark on a journey of self-discovery and friendship, forming unexpected bonds with the diverse cast of characters you meet along the way. The emotional depth of the story took me by surprise, and I found myself genuinely invested in the struggles and triumphs of my feline protagonist.

Moreover, the attention to detail in Stray is unparalleled. From the intricate alleyways to the bustling marketplaces, every corner of the city feels alive and brimming with personality. And let's not forget about the adorable protagonist â€“ the animations and expressions of the cat are so lifelike that I couldn't help but feel a deep connection to my virtual companion.

In addition to its captivating story and world-building, Stray also offers plenty of engaging puzzles and challenges to keep you entertained for hours on end. Whether you're navigating treacherous rooftops or solving clever environmental puzzles, there's never a dull moment in this enchanting adventure.

Overall, Stray is a masterpiece of game design that deserves all the praise it can get. With its charming characters, stunning visuals, and heartfelt story, it's a must-play experience for gamers of all ages. Trust me, you won't want to miss out on this unforgettable journey through the streets of Stray.

I'm in love with this game. It is absolutely a phenomenal masterpiece, a gem indeed.

The storytelling is impactful, bringing emotional feeling towards the cat and robots. 

It's uncommon with games nowadays having this impact. If you've ever played any games from Fumito Ueda (Shadow of the Colossus/Ico/The Last Guardian) you'll know that feeling I'm talking about. It's truly special.

The level of detail here is admiring. Charming while making you feel immersed the entire time. You can tell the devs put their heart and soul into this game.

From the atmospheric environments, the physics, animations and the soundtrack that compliments it all, really is refreshing.

I recommend this game for everyone.

Stray is the epitome of a game built with love to me. The visuals are of course incredible, playing a kitty and having a meow button is ALSO incredible and fun and silly, but the worldbuilding/NPCs and gameplay are fantastic. It's intuitive and cleverly designed - the way pathways are laid out, the way your abilities and how you interact with the world changes at times. Sometimes you feel like a superhero - and sometimes you really are just a lost cat in a strange and frightening world, and that made the experience really special.

Well just finished the game.

Gotta say, it was quite the experience, visually the game is beautiful, the story of the world is quite intriguing, (although the ending was kinda lacking) and the protagonist is really charming, a simple cat. 

Gameplay wise, its pretty simple, largely focused on exploration, puzzle solving and some stealth/run sections, its a good game for those looking for something relaxing.

Its a pretty short game, took me around 6 hours to complete while trying to explore everything, there isnt really much replay value im afraid, with most of it relying on getting achievements and collectibles. 

The highlight is obviously the protagonist, our little fur ball, they did a good job at replicating cat behavior, one interaction that gave me chuckle is when you first get the backpack, cat owners will most likely know why ;) you can mess around quite a bit, throwing items into the floor, messing up with people, scratching everything you see, sleeping, etc, if you wanna be a cat, this is the game. 

A few complains though, the game could really use some optimization, the FPS would sometimes really drop on certain areas, and in my case i ran into an issue with my controls not working which essentially locked my game until i managed a way around it, so, might be better to wait a few days for some patches to fix those issues, but its possible to play the game. 

Overall, i really liked the game, i would give it a 7/10, Meow.

Very good cat game. Interesting story, I love how they reveal things as you play through the game. Great details and animation! There is a small section that includes a bit of horror - I was not aware of this but I got through it. Definitely worth playing! One of my fav parts was when you could climb up onto the robot's chest and take a nap. Oh and the guitar part. So cozy!

It kinda funny that after release of Half-Life, all of gaming industry realised that there is an option for complex stories and topics in video games, that they are not just about pointless shooting and looting. It is also funny, that come to be in 2024 we are like back in the 90s, where most of big games are about pointless grinding, live services and skin packs, but not the stories the games tell. That is why having such a small diamond, like Stray, but the diamond nevertheless, in my opinion, is very crucial for the industry and a must-play for everyone.
Also, this game is very beginner-friendly, so if you don't play games, this is a very good entry point into gaming for you.

It's been a while since I picked up a new game and finished it in one sitting. What an absolutely gorgeous and hideous world at the same time. I just couldn't put my gamepad down. I did have to use a guide a couple of times, because some things were just not exactly obvious and I didn't like the stealthy parts with sentinels, but other than that I don't really have any real complaints. Also the game is absolutely great from the technical perspective. I did have to inject HDR through Special K, but that's the only flaw. The game is beautiful the whole time and runs smooth as butter compared to a lot of similarly good looking AAA games (looking at you, Cyberpunk). 8 hours might be a bit too short for some people, for me it was just perfect.

Cute game, nice environment, but not only too short, but also not enough gameplay or immersion. Looks like a demo that got a little bit bigger than intended.
Not really cyberpunk dystopia, but rather Kowloon Hong Kong with weathered robots. 
Puzzles are simple, interactions are very limited (robots have only 1 or 2 things to say, everybody is giving you fetch quests). The cat controls are very basic and restricted. No free jumping for example.
The 'enemies' are very basic, but break up the chill exploration. In my opinion, they were not needed and I'd rather have more exploration and lore.
Quite early in you already know where the story is going and why the 'world' is what it is. After that, there is no more mystery. 
The end felt rushed (also short game time doesn't help) and left too many simple open questions on what happens with the characters in that world and with the cat.
Even as a cat-person I really don't understand why everyone is so impressed by this upscaled demo.

You are better off just watching someone's playthrough online (can be done within 2 hours, not rushed). It is in my opinion not worth more than 5-10 Euro.

Excellent work, so much so that it makes me seriously identify the few shortcomings in it and hope it's perfect.
1. fixed lens to cat distance, with 3D graphics, darker scenes, and more close-ups, it tends to lead to visual fatigue and vertigo, which reduces the gaming experience, so I hope I can freely adjust the distance between the lens and the cat;
2. The process is short. I hope that in the next generation of works to grow the main plot, and add some subplots.

At the end of the story, the cat walks out of the city without explaining whether the cat is reunited with its 3 companions; B-12 does not completely destroy itself, is there a possibility of resurrection; the out-of-control bacteria dies under daylight, but does this mean that it still survives in the sewers without daylight and spreads to the outside shaded areas due to the opening of the dome; does the authoritarian force in the middle zone continue to rule in another way and if it is overthrown, does a new totalitarian force emerge? Does all this suspense mean that Stray II is being planned? I look forward to Stray II.

Good game. Tells the tale of a cat that falls from the surface to the lower levels of an abandoned facility and its journey back to the surface. Along the way, the cat meets various inhabitants including robots that have gained sentience, a strange lifeform that has evolved from simply eating garbage and a peculiar robot companion that guides you along your journey. 

Run time if you're trying to collect everything on your 1st go should be around 7-8 hours. If you replay chapters to find the stuff you've missed you can expect roughly 10 hours. There were some performance issues that a quick trip to the Discussion board solved. The game runs better in DirectX12 with ray tracing disabled. Even with that though I still noticed that although I was running at >100fps that the game would hitch from time to time and that the frame rate would tank down to 30fps in dimly lit areas. Not a deal breaker as the experience was still immersive. 

This is a pretty game to look at with a formulaic story, low key atmospheric music and good execution on the gameplay front. You can mod in your favourite breed of cat simply enough if the default orange one isn't to your liking. Would I have considered this for game of the year back when it came out? No but it's a pretty solid title nevertheless.

When I saw advertisements for this game I chuckled thinking this was some "Goat Simulator" type game with all the wrong intentions. Little did I know this game was a stroke of genius. This has such a unique idea to it that made me regret those initial premonitions. Stray, at every turn within the storyline, had me curious what was going to happen next. I loved the problem solving aspect and was honestly stumped on a few levels, but refreshingly awarded as I figured it out. The animation was great in my opinion and really gave that extra depth to the story. The world building and storytelling were the key essential to my immersion into this storybook that really made me feel something dark but hopeful in the right ways. This is a must play for gamers across the board (and even people WHO DONT LIKE CATS!)

Game is almost perfect for what it sets out to be, and I thought that my only complaint would be a little forced action sequences.

Unfortunately, my BIG complaint is the ending. It seems that somewhere at the end writer decided that the story is not dramatic enough and sucker punch is an ideal way to increase dramatic value. By doing that, they almost broke the story. Itâ€™s not telegraphed in any way in the story, it does not feel justified by conditions of the final episode, it does not work as an ending point to any of the topics of the story.

If you are ok with ignoring the ending, I would strongly recommend. Meow! Maw. Maw. Mee.

fantastic idea, great novel game development, well done environs, more puzzles than action, so can get tedious at some points, yet remains amazingly fun and engaging, the storytelling is engaging all the way through

Absolutely beautiful game. I typically do not play single player games but this caught my eye and boy am I happy I bought it. I would love to see a sequel just seeing what happens after what happens. If not though I understand. I  love this game and if you love cats and futuristic cities and puzzles you'll love this game.

Edit: I do not play single player games because I was raised playing competitive fighter  / shooter games so usually I would quickly lose interest in story games.. I know it's sad but that's why I chose to leave this game a review and even update my  review again to express how amazing this game is. The characters are warm and witty the world environment is amazing and beautiful. I wish I could play this game again for the first time.
I thought it was going to be a cute exploration game...... it was, I just wasn't prepared for all the emotions that came with it. 10/10, 5 stars, 100% recommend. Just expect to feel things.

I love this game so much. The visuals are so beautiful, the world building is so well done and the world feels so immersive and interesting to explore. The story is also very beautiful and really makes you think. For a game that falls into a rather shorter format (can be quite comfortably played in 3 to 4 hours), it offers so much and it is gorgeous to look at. And the most important thing - you get to play as a CAT! With all the perks that come with that of course. 10/10, I will always recommend this game to everyone I know.

I was sad to leave the world of Stray. Brilliant world-building combined with a simple but engaging story.

I'd highly recommended this for casual gamers or beginners as the movement mechanics are very simple (the cat doesn't allow itself to fall off things for example) and there are only a few parts of the game which involve more than basic skill with a controller, and that is usually just sprinting past enemies.

For hardcore gamers, this game is easy but still enjoyable if you're the sort of person to read the dialogue and be interested in the story and sights.

While it is a short game, the story is wonderful. My first playthrough took me just under 6 hours. I was missing a lot of B-12's memories and some of the badges. As I'm writing this, I just finished my 2nd playthrough. There's still some achievements for me to get, but I got all of B-12's memories this time and all of the badges and just hit 10 hours of total playtime. I will most definitely play it again at some point. My only negative thing I have to say about it is that Doc got stuck and I had to reload on both playthroughs, but that's such a small thing that it really doesn't even bother me that much. I would love another game like this. Perhaps a 2nd Stray would be too much to ask for, but that's just how much I love this game :')

The cat (Felis catus), commonly referred to as the domestic cat or house cat, is the only domesticated species in the family Felidae. Recent advances in archaeology and genetics have shown that the domestication of the cat occurred in the Near East around 7500 BC. It is commonly kept as a house pet and farm cat, but also ranges freely as a feral cat avoiding human contact. It is valued by humans for companionship and its ability to kill vermin. Because of its retractable claws it is adapted to killing small prey like mice and rats. It has a strong flexible body, quick reflexes, sharp teeth, and its night vision and sense of smell are well developed. It is a social species, but a solitary hunter and a crepuscular predator. Cat communication includes vocalizations like meowing, purring, trilling, hissing, growling, and grunting as well as cat body language. It can hear sounds too faint or too high in frequency for human ears, such as those made by small mammals. It also secretes and perceives pheromones.

Great game, my points 10 out of 10. This is only one game made by BlueTwelve Studio and definitely every part of the game: locations, personalities, the story made by heart. The story that you discovery during your journey on the game, which is basically postapocalyptic closed city. Basically combining game experience and watching movies.  
The game itself doesn't looke like some other games, it is really different experience. Playing as a cat, jumping on tables, walking on roofs even you can scratch claws and do meowing! really leaving the cat live. The game recommends to use gamepad, that is true, definitely  for comfortable game and to really enjoy the process you need to have some joystick, even simple one. Only the drawback I could mention that the game is quite short but detail of every locaiton more than compensates for this shortcoming. Definitelly reccomend to play.

I got this game when it first came out and I can say that I thoroughly enjoyed it. The platforming, story, and just the whole game was fantastic! it gives the player a good amount of difficulty without being too hard and the puzzles probably wont make your brain hurt. One thing I really enjoyed about the game was the goofy little side things and the attention to detail that you can see with your cat, like its interaction with paint can in the dead city and the robots reaction to the cat snuggles! I recommend this game to literally EVERYONE I meet because I love it sooooo much. I keep ramble writing but its an amazing and well made game that doesn't have a HUGE time commitment so I definitely recommend it; and to be fair my review MIGHT be a BIT bias however I truly believe that this is a 10/10 game and I would do anything to go back in time and play it again, definite MUST PLAY!

Stray is wonderfully paced, especially for the amount of extra content in the game. I believe Stray speaks heavily on the self-destructiveness and in-harmony humankind has with nature while trying to advance technologically. Beautiful game, beautiful meaning, beautiful characters, beautiful dynamics. My only constructive criticism would that the graphics and mechanics could be better for a 2022 game. Otherwise, amazing (8/10).

No game is perfect, but Stray comes pretty close for me. It's everything it needs to be: good cat movement and exploration, stunning cyberpunk environment, haunting soundtrack, and a story and characters that at least kept me intrigued throughout the experience. Now I crave an open world cat game with even more physics objects to enjoy and will let me perform any action at any time without requiring prompts.

I really wanted to love this :( Unfortunately the lack of actual control you have as the cat completely took me out of the game. This isn't a 3D platforming game, this is a storytelling game. Don't get me wrong, the story is AMAZING, but I really thought I'd just be a cat, able to run, jump, and climb wherever I wanted in the world. The movement is more like hold forward and spam the jump button, you are told exactly when and where to jump, and there are only like 3 times when you have to do actual gaming, the rest plays itself. Play it for the story if you're interested, and if it's on sale, don't play it if you're excited about the gameplay, there just isn't much there, especially considering the price. No replayability.

Stray is a wonderful mix of great visuals, compelling storytelling and endearing progression. Itâ€™s a fairly short but sweet story set in a dystopian future where humanity is missing with its legacy left behind, which you explore as a little orange cat who has been separated from its family. I am already biased with regards to this being a huge cat lover, so my heartstrings were well and truly tugged with every obstacle this little cat faced throughout the game. Itâ€™s really clear that the developers know cats well, as you can do all manner of cat behaviours, such as tearing up carpets, yowling and climbing effortlessly.

Itâ€™s a real joy to play, the movement feels good and tight and emulates the agility you would expect from playing as a cat. The storytelling is wholly told through exposition, until you reach the first hub of the game. The atmosphere is great, with neon signage and plant-life breaking through the industrial subterranean setting.

The only major negative I feel like I should bring up are the Zurks. Essentially they act as the main antagonist in the game, though they act without reason or malice â€“ theyâ€™re basically evolved bacteria that I assume want to eat you. The problem lies in the fact that whenever they appear in the game, the chilled out aspect quickly changes to you rushing through those sections and sometimes getting overwhelmed â€“ but it can get quite frustrating sometimes. Overall I think this detracts from the overall positive feeling of the game, and I feel as though the game would be better without those sections altogether.

There are also stealth sections which can get annoying; Iâ€™m no stranger to games like Metal Gear, but when it hit the fan at least in games like that you have the backup plan of going in guns blazing â€“ instead you just have to try again.

[b]Pros:[/b]
Excellent gameplay.
Simple at its core.
Heartfelt storyline; havenâ€™t rooted for a protagonists success as much as this for a while.
Loveable characters.
Storyline isnâ€™t in your face.

[b]Cons:[/b]
The ending is a bit too abrupt for my liking.
Game is a little on the short side.
Enemy based sections can be quite frustrating.

Stray is pretty much exactly what it says it is. You play as a cat who falls into a city inhabited by robots, and you must find your way out. You do this by helping the robots and exploring. I found the story interesting, the world beautiful, and the gameplay good enough to keep me engaged.

My biggest complaint is that the game is pretty short for the asking price. In 6 hours I beat the game, got almost all of the achievements, as well as most of the in game collectibles. It would have been really nice to see a few more levels, but I also understand that sometimes adding more just to have more leads to games that feel padded out and makes them worse.

I probably should also mention that there is one level that was bugged to the point where I could not complete it on my PC. Reloading a save and restarting the game and my computer did not help, but the level worked fine on my Steam Deck, even if the frame rate wasnâ€™t that great on the default settings.

Absolutely beautiful graphics and story. The environments are absolutely jaw dropping. This is one of the best games I've played in a while. It was so gorgeous to look at, and had an AMAZING story. It has replay value if you ask me, but in the form of replay it once every year or so and really appreciate the world. 
It really does feel like you're entering a fleshed out world, as a little kitty. Seeing a dystopian world like this from the perspective of a cat is not something I ever thought I wanted, but now that I've seen it, I want everyone to witness it. 

Now, I'm going to say something about this game that I don't think I've ever said before, about any game, even when other people made it happen... I want a movie of this game. I want more people to witness this story. I want a movie made so that everyone can hear this story, and not just people who play video games. Wonderful. 10/10. Buy the game, play the game. Love the game.

Such a beautiful game.

Stray invites players into an enchanting cyberpunk world where feline curiosity takes center stage. Embodying a stray cat navigating the bustling streets of a futuristic city, the game offers a unique and charming perspective on exploration and puzzle-solving. The beautifully crafted environments and attention to detail create an immersive experience that captures the essence of a bustling metropolis through the eyes of a feline adventurer.

Living my best cat life in Stray feels like an absolute joy. The fluid animations and expressive movements of the cat protagonist add a delightful touch to the gameplay. The city's verticality and hidden nooks provide ample opportunities for discovery, and the puzzles, though not overly challenging, strike a perfect balance between engaging and relaxing. The subtle storytelling and ambient sounds immerse players in a world where the charm of being a stray cat takes center stage.

Stray offers a refreshing departure from traditional gaming experiences, allowing players to temporarily escape the human perspective and embrace the whimsical, carefree life of a wandering cat. It's a delightful journey filled with exploration, mystery, and a touch of feline mischief that cat lovers and adventure enthusiasts alike will find endearing.

It is very clear to see that this game was crafted with lots of love for detail. The environments, the lighting, the colors, ... Everything is well thought out and adds to the atmosphere. The story tells the tale of a time after humanity went extinct and offers you pieces of what caused our downfall. It handles themes like evolution, artificial intelligence, compassion, freedom, suffering, wealth inequality and greed. It's heart-wrenching and yet it gives you a glimmer of hope. The soundtrack empathizes this just perfectly. It's phenomenal and easily one of my favorite game soundtracks.

[h1]A Charming Adventure that doesn't Overstay its Welcome[/h1]

I've been looking forward to Stray ever since it was first announced over a year ago, and I am happy to say that I wasn't disappointed. The main things that you do in stray is solve traversal and "story" puzzles, the latter of which are similar to that of point and click games without the frustration that is associated with such games. While doing such activities you'll find yourself exploring a neon lit city populated primarily by human-like robots. All of these robots are oozing with charm making your time on this adventure an absolute pleasure. However, Stray is a very short game, especially if you do not seek out any side content. Despite this, I didn't mind the price tag as I felt that the quality of the game made up for the length. The game is gorgeous and there is very little bloat. I believe that Stray is a must-play, but I understand if you wish to wait for a sale though.

*SPOILERS AHEAD*
I've been following Stray since its first trailer over two years ago, and my god was it worth the wait in every way possible. The game has some of the best scenery and lighting I've seen to date, everything was vivid and real. The environments rival Portal 2 in terms of conveying an overgrown dystopia (In the areas that are an overgrown dystopia that is). The cities are full of life and color that is all packed into such tight and cramped spaces. The quality of the animations on the robot residents play a big role in showing their body language and mood, and I went through the entire game watching every movement they made. The game has a very self contained story and doesn't play with anything big, you are a lost cat that winds up saving a society of robots that take after their fallen humans. You meet a human turned robot and he helps you on your way to escape the city. He translates the locals, hacks doors, and sacrifices himself a lot. The ending of this game invoked an emotional response in me worse than Red Dead Redemption 2. I must admit the game is extremely bleak, and even in the end left a pang of sadness in me with minimal satisfaction. Almost like they did it on purpose. I'm just silently hoping that after all those loose ends and a single cliffhanger that they planned to make a DLC of sorts, because the ending is just damn depressing. You don't reunite with your original cat family, you don't stay with the robots that you befriended during your journey, and B12 is left dead in the Control Room (with a tiny chance that he's alive thanks to the small cliffhanger at the end). The game builds the world and the history of Walled City 99 through dialogue and secrets found throughout the game, and once you've pieced together the puzzle the game is over and you're left with less than when you started. Was this the point of the game? To tell a depressing story in an already depressing world?
Maybe I'm just looking too far into it and should've taken it at face value, "the cute cat saved the nice robots and got out alive"
Or maybe I'm just too upset about B12. His story was oddly heartfelt to me, and in the end he didn't get anything he wanted.

For a final summary, grief aside.
I'm going to review the game for what it gave to me rather than what I took from it. The game visually is a work of art that is well optimized and extremely atmospheric. The story is told directly and people looking for more can explore the world to learn new information. The parkour/movement aspects of the game are fluid and liberating, and the puzzles are simple but satisfying. The sound design in the music and ambiance is unique, going very well with the visual aesthetics of the dystopian and vibrant city parts of the game. There is a small amount of replayability in things like the Memory system and collectathon fetch-quests.

Overall my unbiased rating of the game is 9/10, a memorable and near perfect experience that leaves a lot up to you in terms of deciding what you make of it. I wont be forgetting Stray.

So, this mostly depends on *why* you want to play games. If you want to play because you enjoy cats and like cyberpunk stories, grab it. If you want to play because of actual gameplay, then don't.

The gameplay is very, very, *very* basic, there is little to no challenge, no new - or interesting - mechanics, so, as a game, it's clearly subpar.

But if you enjoy the thematic / topic, you want a semi-interesting story but that doesn't go to deep topics, enjoy watching cute cats and animations and in general are okay with visuals being like 90% of the entire game, then it's a solid purchase.

About 6-8 hours to complete, about 10 for 100%, so do consider that together with the lack of actual gameplay.

Still, a solid recommendation to be shared with someone, ideally if they aren't that experienced with games in general.

Stray is a purr-fect masterpiece that seamlessly weaves together a beautifully crafted world, stunning art style, meticulous detail, and a captivating narrative. The cityscape is visually enchanting, filled with cozy hideaways and unexpected surprises. The game's attention to detail is astounding, from rain-soaked streets to the bustling life of stray animals.

Stray's gameplay is both intuitive and engaging, allowing you to gracefully navigate the city, solve puzzles, and interact with the environment. The feline perspective adds a unique charm, capturing the essence of a cat's curiosity. The narrative is heartwarming and mysterious, with memorable characters contributing to the overall allure.

As the credits rolled, the anticipation for the sequel was palpable. Stray is not just a game; it's a fun and unforgettable experience that will leave you eagerly awaiting the next adventure in this remarkable world.

It is with the most certainty I have ever had that I say this is the greatest game I have ever played in my life. The main character, of course, is the best I've ever played as. The other characters you meet along the way are all charming and excellently written. The world of Stray makes you feel like you are right inside it. It feels alive, with so many different characters all with their own personality, and entire swaths of this world to explore. The controls and movement are also the best I've ever had the pleasure of using, making me feel like a parkour professional as I leapt and bounded across this charmingly dystopian yet oddly hopeful universe. The ending made me openly weep, attracting the concerned attention of multiple family members. I cannot recommend this game enough, this review would be longer than the Bible if I tried to explain how much I love this game. I highly recommend you step into the paws of the little Outsider, and open the sky.

Beautiful game, with a nice cyberpunk vibe. The game-play is a bit odd, you play as a detective solving some minor puzzles and searching for locations and people. Aside to that there are action scenes with where you are chased or need to stealth your way through.

So keep in mind if you want to play Stray (and I think you should definitely do) that it is a pretty relaxing game where you explore this strange world/city with a cat.

It is not a difficult game and it is easy to pick up.

Pros:
 - Wonderful art direction
 - Nice story
 - Good game-play loop
 - Overall just fun to play

Cons: 
 - Relatively short (less then 10 hours to see everything)
 - Mods really make the game shine (no Ray-tracing out of the box, missing some aliasing etc)
 - Pacing is a bit odd at times and ending feels a bit rushed. (although this is nitpicky.)
 - Auto-save is frequent but sometimes at odd places. 

Conclusion:
Really original and fun game, definitely recommend this game. Nice to play for 15 minutes and pick it up later too. I can only hope for a Stray 2.

A good story telling experience. The game itself is focused on puzzles. Solve puzzle to progress the storyline which focus on sy-fy elements. There are moments of horror  in the first half the game, but afterwards, it loses those horror.

The game itself feels incomplete however only in its storytelling aspects. It has a great start, but after the first area, the chapters soon quickly feel rushed and incomplete lacking in as many interesting characters, side quests, etc. There feels like their  should be more story, but either didn't have time or money or both to do such things. But, a good story should always leave you with some questions and answer the main one, which in this case it does. After all the main goal is to get back to surface. 

The gameplay is smooth, and pretty straightforward. Only a few times did I get stuck on puzzles and had to go and revisit locations again to see if I missed anything. Even through a second play-through this is true. Only once or twice I had to pause to rethink what the game was trying to introduce without actually throwing a tutorial in your face. 

I recommend doing all the memory side quest. There is no quest log, but each zone or new area has at least one, and that will really bring out the story telling in the area. Do not move forward from that area until you complete those side quest though. You can't go back.

AMAZING GAME

Separated from your other cat companions, you find yourself lost, alone, and injured in the bowels of some kind of city.  You soon discover that you're not alone.  The city is inhabited by humanoid robots who have long forgotten their purpose, and it's up to you to figure out where to go next.

Stray is a unique spin on the third-person game genre.  You play as a cat, but you're not completely alone.  You encounter a robotic companion that helps guide you through your journey and interact with the world, while you also help this companion recover its lost memories.  There are platforming and puzzle elements, some combat, questing, and plenty of exploration.  Visually rich with a unique aesthetic, charming characters, and intuitive game play, Stray will keep you immersed in a subterranean mystery for hours on end.

Pros:

Intuitive controls.  All you need is a keyboard and mouse.  Gamepad is supported and recommended by the devs.
Excellent graphics and great performance, even on older hardware.
Interesting and unique characters and envirnoments.
Great storytelling.  A simple premise that is well executed.
Cut scenes are letterboxed so you know it's a cut scene but you're still "in the world" with very smooth transitions.
It's about a cat.  You like cats, don't you?  Who doesn't like cats?

Cons:

Sometimes the third-person camera movement can be a little disorienting for some.  If you're sensitive to motion keep this in mind.
Occasionally the jump interaction icon can be hard to get into focus in some places, making a necessary jump difficult.  This isn't game breaking and it only happens a few specific times during the game.
Some of the action sequences can have strange difficulty ramping, going from absurdly easy to instant death depending on  where you are in the game.  Not game breaking but it can be frustrating in certain points.
If you die during an action sequence sometimes the checkpoint makes you backtrack a little father than should be necessary.

Bugs Encountered:

None.  Game ran flawlessly for me.

Final Thoughts:

Worth the price.

This game about a stray cat made me cry at the end. 10/10

I love it when great games make an impact in the mainstream!
"Stray" has a button dedicated to meow and that is all you need to know if you are a casual gamer who is looking to get a taste of what is currently making noise.

Apart from that, this is a very atmospheric experience, half a walking simulator on four legs, half a mysterious adventure game that presents a very endearing story through a masterfully built setting.
There is an inspiring mix of sci-fi and post-apocalyptic nature retaking its own world that makes for an excellent emphasis on our furry main character. If there are no humans to lead the way, might as well leave the task to a cat.
And that might just be the social comment that the writer of the plot is trying to get through. By inhabiting its world with just robots that imitate human beings and fall short of feeling really human, we may have to be reminded here that humanity sometimes comes from non-human beings. A cat represents all that is human and leads a bunch of "only faint reminders of human beings" to the right direction in life.

There are two excelling positives in this game:
- It is very well polished, every detail has been taken care of and the environmental storytelling is always there to set for a great story with a healthy dose of mystery. Very well infused with an amazing soundtrack and perfectly measured chapters.
- The developers have seen cats before and it's easy to tell. Not only in the obvious additions like pushing things off the edge but also through the whole mechanic of the game that implicitly forces you to think like a cat and very strongly sets in the player a cat mentality right from the start of the game.

The only downside:
- The content of the game gives for around 10 hours, sitting back to enjoy the scenery on many occasions, hunting for an extra here and there, and maybe some of the achievements. That is it though, a short experience with a few brilliant ideas put together. I strongly hope the developers will come back with a second part of the game in the future.

Overall "Stray" presents us with a unique feeling and many original ideas from developers who clearly have a great love for the art of video game making. This is another strong statement for single-player story-focused experiences.

I recommend this game to you with a very special caveat: You must be a cat-lover. Not because the game is bad if youâ€™re not, but because I donâ€™t think itâ€™s made for non-cat-lovers, and so itâ€™d be wrong to judge this game from the perspective of its unintended audience.

By this I only mean to highlight the fact that this game is - fundamentally - a walking simulator. Most of the fun I had was just from simple things you can do like abusing the meow button and feeling this warm fuzzy feeling inside while controlling our tiny little feline hero. If thatâ€™s not your thing then youâ€™d probably be playing a very different game than what Iâ€™m about to describe and in all honesty I feel I lack both the perspective and the objectivity to judge whether this alternative experience is worth recommending.

That said, Stray offers (to cat lovers) a unique and immersive experience in a BEAUTIFULLY animated world full of personalities and intrigue. I love how the story remains as cute as its protagonist throughout except a couple moments of ingenious Lovecraftian horror. It ties up really well and feels surprisingly (in a good way) emotional. Also Iâ€™m surprised to find out the cat was entirely animated and there wasnâ€™t any mo-cap involved - that it captures the quintessence of our perception of feline movement in the end is a testament to the tremendous talent the team must have for this game to be this good. Also the score is one of the best Iâ€™ve heard yet, really makes the world come to life and adds to the wholesome tone of the game.

All in all just a fantastically made game and I hope it gets enough fanfare to spawn another sequel, or at least a spiritual successor? A dog game, a spider gameâ€¦you name it.

Stray is an interesting game. It has a nice concept, a great art direction, beautiful graphics BUT it is SO SO SHORT (Just above 4 hours) that I can write this review in bullet points and still don't miss an aspect. LET'S GO!

1) Story
     a) Nice concept of being a cat in a post-human android world
     b) Few but good characters like Momo, B-12 and Clementine.
     c) The game is very short and none of the set-ups actually pays off. 
     d) Because of its brevity, a lot of potential (like the dystopian sentinels or the plague) is squandered (or set for a sequel)
     e) Because of that, all the answers the game provides feel rushed and somewhat underwhelming

2) Gameplay
     a) Mostly a puzzle platformer with some chase action and some stealth sections
     b) The jumping is scripted. That is good at platforming (so you won't fall down) but terrible at chases (if you miss the prompt, you're dead)
     c) The zurk chases are awful and the deathray useless
     d) Stealth is ok, but hastely cramped into the last section of the game
     e) Could use a bit more variety at puzzle platforming (The camera "mission" was a nice windowdressing to the mechanic)

3) Environment & Collectibles
     a) Small areas packed with character. Great variety of environment
     b) Slums and Midcity are great! Small, fun and full with things to interact. This is how it SHOULD be done.
     c) There are collectibles (memories and badges) BUT while they are relatively interwoven with the main story in the first part, they are completely buried in the second part. 

4) Visuals
     a) Great graphics, utilized properly. 
     b) Great art direction that enhances the world-building. The game is the EPITOME of visual storytelling.
     c) Kudos to the "Open city" scene. If the game took the time with the rest of the world, that would be the most impactful scene in recent gaming history.  

There you go. The game's only fault is being 4 hours long. If it were twice or triple that time (e.g like Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice or A Plague Tale: Innocence) and let you connect with the world, the characters and the plot this would be hailed as a masterpiece of AA gaming history.

Amazing game.  Catch it on sale, but worth every penny.  Fun premise - a stray cat gets lost and meets a bunch of robots while trying to get back to his family.   No human voices the entire game is unusual and surprisingly refreshing change of pace.  If you like point and click adventure RPG, then this is right up your alley.  A game pad or joystick is helpful, but not required.  

A nice touch that you can turn off "Show cat death" in settings if you are playing with younger and/or more sensitive gamers.  

(Mild Spoiler ahead)

Other than a few scenes mid-game in a sewer with some scary-looking baddies, the violence was pretty minor.  I thought my kids (who are sensitive gamers) would be more frightened of the "eyeballs" and the little scampering baddies who my son dubbed "potatoes" since they look like potatoes with limbs and mouths.  Your cat can get hit by lasers at one point in the game, but again if you shut off the "show cat death", it just goes to a death screen and you don't see anything bad happen to the kitty.

Stray is in essence a cat simulator but with a full story packed in. You play as an unnamed ginger tabby (cat) that (within the first 5-10 minutes) gets separated from all your cat buddies after you fall into a large sewer drain. The over-arching story is just you trying to get back to the surface and mingle with your feline friends again.. As you continue your adventure you soon realise there is much more under the surface (literally and figuratively) than meets the eye. The whole gameplay experience was very relaxing and relatively easy to 100% (the one exception being the "[spoiler]Can't Cat-ch Me[/spoiler]" achievement which seems to require a lot more luck than skill to achieve). Overall though, my experience was brilliant, really hoping they make a sequel.

Fair warning, I finished this game in about 5 hours, so take that into consideration if you're going to feel butthurt that you didn't get to play for hundreds of hours for the price. Was it worth it on sale? Absolutely.

The world itself is beautiful and the sense of immersion in this post-apocalyptic cyberpunk city is excellent. Many critics of the game have complained that it is too simple, that the puzzles are too easy, and that the story is only mediocre. I don't think it's a bad thing that this game employs simple mechanics and easy puzzles and I would say that the story is one that's been told before, but is charming and heartfelt. This is a casual adventure with intuitive and linear platforming for the most part, but with a few stops along the way that are more open for exploration. You spend just enough time on each piece to understand another part of what went down in this world and I enjoyed each of the "outsiders" and their personalities.  

If you need something less intense this weekend, this is a great game that you can complete in an afternoon.  Again, I love how beautiful the game is as well, so I may even play it through once more to ensure I see all of the content.

"Stray" is a game that immerses players in the role of a curious cat, proving to be a captivating experience for feline enthusiasts. From the initial moments of guiding this virtual feline, players find themselves immersed in a fascinating and enigmatic universe, full of intricacies and revelations that mirror the innate curiosity of cats.

The first standout feature is the meticulous detailing in replicating cat movements and idiosyncrasies. Every motion exudes fluidity and authenticity, be it the gentle purring or the nimble, graceful leaps. It's so adorable!

The game's setting serves as a spectacle in its own right. The cyberpunk city, replete with narrow alleys, accessible rooftops, and concealed nooks, offers an enthralling terrain for exploration. The graphics are breathtaking, showcasing an extraordinary devotion to detail, from sunlight filtering through buildings to reflections on glass surfaces. Each shadowy alley and rooftop beckons exploration, fostering an environment conducive to continuous discovery.

The accompanying soundtrack also merits acclaim. Combining melodic undertones with urban ambiance, it seamlessly integrates with the game's atmosphere. Distant meows, soft footfalls, and even the rustling of the wind during alleyway traversals contribute layers of immersion, genuinely conveying the sensation of prowling the streets as a cat.

The narrative, centered around a lost cat navigating a society of robots, is both intriguing and well-crafted. Interactions with other characters human and robotic alike are conveyed uniquely through non-verbal communication and contextual cues. This innovative approach aligns with the silent disposition of cats, introducing an additional layer of complexity to understanding the unfolding storyline.

Yet, the game transcends mere narrative, incorporating a myriad of side missions and optional tasks that enrich the gameplay. This encourages players to delve into every nook and cranny of the city, engaging with its inhabitants. These supplementary missions offer substantial rewards, prolonging the overall experience and providing additional hours of entertainment.

In essence, the game emerges as a feast for cat enthusiasts, seamlessly blending a faithful portrayal of feline behavior with a distinctive perspective on exploring the world through a cat's eyes.

I didn't really know much about this game going in other than how much effort had been put into the cat animations and expressions, so was really just expecting to just be running around as a cat harassing the local robot population. Which to be fair you can do a lot of stuff like knocking tins of paint off of tables, clawing at rugs and generally being an asshole.

What I wasn't expecting was a short but captivating story about AI and what it means to be human or sentient, as well as some genuinely heartfelt moments and likeable robot characters. 
Throughout it's brief journey Stray is cute, heartening and enjoyable. It is also tense and unsettling at points but ultimately concludes in a satisfying way.

10/10 will stop to make claw biscuits on every rug, every time.
SOMA but with a cat, beautiful graphics and a happy ending.

It's a nice puzzle platformer with an interesting enough story. But not a 'cat game' I was expecting as a cat person. The game is fine, our feline protag is cute, but gameplay lacks 'catness'. Doesn't feel like I'm playing a cat, and I'm not talking about a nocturne predator needing a flashlight or a cat doing quests and cooperating altruisticly (that's what dogs are for actually). It's just there is no sense of graceful wildness and natural independence, and those are crucial characteristics that I value the most in cats.

This game is absolutely phenomenal, everything from the goofy lil characters to the adventures your little guy goes through is so well crafted that it leaves the player hooked, at least thats what it did to me. The story got me so immersed that i was at the final chapter before i knew it. Yeah, the game is really not that long but i would not have it any other way. For what it is, the length of the story seems to be made just right, and now im begging for a sequel. The graphics and general style of the game made me check the requirements again because (coming from someone with not much knowledge of computers) the game is really well optimised. The environment looks so rich with colour and that ending -- ooh that ending, beautiful in looks and way more. Caps for emphasis: PLAY THIS GAME BLINDLY, DONT LOOK AT GAMEPLAY AND DONT YOU DARE PEEK AT THE STORY. Playing this game with no previous knowledge (even though i knew it existed) was one of the best decisions i could have ever made.

[h1]Stray: A Purrfectly Flawed Adventure[/h1]

[u]Story and Setting:[/u]

Players control a [b]stray cat[/b] who must navigate a neon-lit cyberpunk city inhabited by robots.
The [i]world is beautifully crafted[/i], with towering skyscrapers, bustling alleyways, and hidden secrets to discover.
The game's atmosphere is a unique blend of cyberpunk grit and feline whimsy, making it a joy to explore.

[h2]Gameplay:[/h2]

Gameplay is focused on exploration, puzzle-solving, and platforming.
Players can [strike]jump, climb, scratch, and meow[/strike] their way through the environment.
The [b]controls are tight and responsive[/b], making it a pleasure to control the agile cat.
The [i]puzzles are clever and varied[/i], but never too challenging.

[h2]Purrfect Imperfections:[/h2]

The game's biggest flaw is its [strike]short length[/strike]. The main story can be completed in around four hours.
It [i]lacks some of the depth and complexity[/i] found in other adventure games.
The story is relatively light on character development and emotional impact.

[h2]Overall:[/h2]

Stray is a charming and atmospheric adventure game with innovative cat-like gameplay. However, its short length, lack of depth, and limited story prevent it from being a truly great game.

[h3]Recommendation:[/h3]

If you're looking for a short, relaxing, and visually stunning adventure game, Stray is definitely worth checking out. However, if you're looking for a deep and complex story-driven experience, you may be disappointed.

[hr]

Notable points:

The game's soundtrack is excellent, with a blend of cyberpunk and ambient music that perfectly complements the atmosphere.
The game features a number of collectibles, including Zurks (small, annoying creatures) and memories of the cat's past.
There is no photo mode in the game, which is a surprising omission given the game's beautiful visuals.

[h3]Final Verdict:[/h3]

Stray is a 9 out of 10 paws. It's a purrfectly enjoyable experience, a nine-lives masterpiece.

The game is easy enough to understand but hard enough to encourage exploration. I remember when I was a kid and played Uncharted 2 for the first time. It was a wild game that kept you on the edge of your seat. this was one of the most beautiful games i have ever played. the graphics were PHENOMENAL, and what really added to that feature was the zoom in function of the controls, i mean that made for such a nice experience while playing the game . the level design was top notch, not too straightforward but challenging enough to make me think and then move forward in a logical way but definitely not too difficult by any standards. 
my absolute favourite part about the game was all the little details that tailor to the needs of the everyday cat owner, obviously there will be an influx of cat owners playing this game and the small touches added to the game that showcase all the small things that cats get up to that only cat owners would know about really added an element of personality to the game. 
i have to say this was one of my favourite games of all time, just so sad it took me only 6 hrs roughly to complete.

Stray is  a wonderful game, with a very engaging story and a cute protagonist that was very fun to play.   Jumping around, scratching things for no reason, taking catnaps in implausible places, meowing randomly, cuddling up to strange robots, and doing other cat stuff for the sake of doing cat stuff was quite fun.  The puzzles were not particularly difficult to solve but hard enough to be satisfying (and no need to look up answers from the streamers which was nice).   The visuals, music and sound were  very rich and appropriate for the mood the game was setting.  The action sequences were also quite challenging without being over the top difficult.   Using elusiveness as the main way to overcome overwhelming odds was quite fun.  

 There are parts of the game that are downright terrifying (being chased and hunted by the ravenous enemy critters in particular), so maybe this game would not be the best choice for small children who might otherwise find playing a game as a cat to be appealing.  There is also some really  creepy environmental imagery at parts that I found cool, but would probably be to too intense for the youngest players.

My only beef with the game was that it was over in just under 15 hours, and with my mediocre gaming skills I had to replay some of the more twitchy parts of the game four or five times to get through them.  A pro gamer could probably finish this game in ten or twelve hours perhaps.

The world-building is so exquisite that I'm left heartbroken that [spoiler] I can't go back after the ceiling is opened.[/spoiler] 10/10 for beauty and originality but I really wish there was something to do after beating it other than beating it again with more accolades.

I wish to place my summary before my review just do to how amazing this game is;
   Summary:
I cannot recommend this game enough. If you are reading reviews before diving in, I beg you to please just give this game a try so noting gets spoiled for you. Wait for a sale if you must, but a 100% blind play through is an absolute must.

   Review:
I cannot bring myself to call this a game. While it literally is by definition, I wish to only call it an experience.

The atmosphere and environments are carefully crafted in a way that I haven't seen "triple a" titles replicate in a long time. While most titles are half baked, this is well made and had plenty of time in the oven.

I think I can easily explain the gameplay as "parkour" just with a cat. Moving from one ledge to another is fluid, clean, and consistent. If you're a speed runner this is your kind of game. In regards to controls, I used a mouse and keyboard and did not experience difficulty. However, the game does recommend a controller if you have one. It is up to you.

Animations and details that you see from the cat models are things that you could only notice if you have lived with cats for a period of time.

In regards to story I refuse to talk about it. Please experience it for yourself. It's short but sweet. Nothing about it over stays it's welcome.

Wow, I finally finished the story for this game and I really did enjoy it. I would consider this an adventure/exploration game with a focus on the storytelling. You play as an orange tabby who gets separated from his fellow felines and accidentally falls into an undercity of sorts. Set in a cyberpunk future where there are seemingly no humans left, just humanoid robots and other wildlife. You soon realize that the place where this cat finds himself is very dangerous and getting back to the surface will be a difficult task. It leads you on a journey where you discover the history of this city and how everything came to be the way that is in the game. I found the setting to be very interesting and I wanted to learn and understand more about this world.

The game only takes about 8-10 hours to complete, more or less. Obviously, it can be done faster if you are just rushing to the end of the game. I chose to take my time and enjoy the scenery and search for collectibles and other pieces of lore scattered about the map. I think the game is definitely worth it for $25-$30, but if you can get it at deeper discount, then that would be even better- it's a deal for $20 or less.

I thought that the graphics looked beautiful, it's built using unreal engine 4 but it still runs really well. I played a good portion of the game on my Steam Deck at well above 30fps (not sure about getting 60fps though). They recently released a Mac port of the game for newer Apple computers using Apple Silicon. I have a 2020 13" MacBook Pro with M1 processor and only 8GB of RAM and the game still ran very well. It features MetalFX upscaling, which is Apple's answer to FSR/DLSS. My primary 4070 desktop ran the game at over 100fps with highest settings at 3840x1600 resolution. It basically runs great on all platforms and is very scalable in terms of performance.

I think this is a really cool indie game that doesn't compromise on visual fidelity. I love pixel art/retro 2D games as well, but it's nice to see an indie game that can match AAA games in terms of graphics/fidelity. I wish more indie developers were making games like this. Also, we need more games where you play as a cat, there are so few of them. I have always had a cat as pet, ever since I was a small child, so I really appreciate a game that is an appreciation/celebration of cats.

If you're anything like me, the fact that Stray was a game where you got to play as a cat and the fact that it was published by Annapurna was enough to place it in the "maybe to definitely" buy category.

When the game was brand new, I found it a little expensive, and so I waited for it to go on sale to finally make the purchase.Â  And after playing it the recommendation is still in the same "maybe to definitely" category.

There should be no bones about the amount of content in this game.Â  What's there is certainly beautiful and charming, but it lasts, in my case, a little under five hours.Â  The game is decidedly wonderful and the cyberpunk aesthetic and story is something up my alley so I found it easy to connect with.Â  It's an Action/Adventure game with some light puzzles and stealth here and there with what's in between something akin to a cat walking simulator.

I can safely say that TLC was put into this game and it will shine through as you play it.Â  Though the monotony of dark underground cyberpunk slums may wear a little thin, none of the environments feel cookie-cutter and there are times where the beauty of the game is striking.

Also playing as a cat feels seamless and enjoyable.Â  It feels like a parkour Mirror's Edge type experience through a cat's perspective.Â  When the game is over you'll definitely wish there was more.

The game is quite linear and the replay value isn't particularly high, maybe good for 2 playthroughs.Â  There are no additional endings, and the side content isn't too dense or rewarding.Â  I definitely recommend the game but I also would push to wait for a sale or a discount.Â  Though the price of entry for such a cinematic experience that lasts longer than a full length feature will definitely be of value for many of you.Â  Especially if you love those fuzzy little bastards.
