Stray has charmed its way into my heart with its unique take on gaming. The cat mechanics add an adorable and immersive layer to the overall experience, making it a joy to navigate the cybernetic world as a feline explorer.

The game's visuals are captivating, and the attention to detail enhances the futuristic atmosphere. I found myself enthralled by the simplicity and wonder of the storyline, and the puzzles seamlessly integrated into the narrative added a satisfying level of challenge.

The intuitive gameplay, combined with the endearing cat perspective, creates a truly enjoyable journey. Stray doesn't rely on flashy features but instead captures players with its charm and creativity.

I'm eagerly anticipating another installment, hoping for more delightful adventures and perhaps new feline mechanics. Stray is a game that has left a pawprint on my gaming memories, deserving a wholehearted 5-star rating.

hello! in my opinion, stray is an amazing game that i have replayed countless times. the characters are all amazing, and each robot has their own unique personality. the graphics are wonderful, and the soundtrack is so good that i could fall asleep to it. there are so many different areas to explore, and robots to meet! there are even fun side quests that aren't too difficult. the puzzles in the game aren't that hard either, which makes the game super enjoyable. one of the best parts of the game: you can meow as much as you want! this game has an amazing story containing you and your friend b12 as the main protagonists, and a few more protagonists like the outsiders that are there to help you! this game contains amazing antagonists too, and amazing plot twists that'll leave your jaw dropped. the only con to this game is the gameplay is short leaving you thirsty for more. i really hope that a stray 2 get released because i cannot get enough of this cat game! i would recommend this game to ages 8+ because there's some animated blood, alcohol references, and a very minimum foul language for parents who are wondering if this game is ok for their kids to get. overall, highly recommended!!
Be a cat, do cat things, and solve puzzles along the way in this platform game. Super fun and was able to help a local rescue with a much needed donation of food and supplies~

There's a lot done right here. I know there were some glitches and bugs that were happening on release, but honestly that doesn't detract from the story and world-building here. I just wrote a review on "Firmament", and this is a polar opposite to it - In a good way.

I really like the cohesiveness of the world, the locations unfold in a way that all sticks together. It made you want to play to the end, just to see all of it. The lighting is top-notch. Well done. When I find myself making snapshots just to set as my wallpaper, you know you've done a great job.

I won't reveal much about the story, the exploration is what makes this work after all - I'll just say that when this team rests and decides to possibly do another project, I'll be waiting, because you guys know how to make a great game.

Good job, it was very rewarding to play and experience.

Great atmosphere, very Interesting story, lots of exploring and, best of all, you play as a cat! I really enjoyed the game and am very glad I bought it.

The good: graphics, story, level design, exploring, unique protagonist, collectibles that actually add to the story
The bad: Some checkpoints are way too far apart (8 minutes) with lots of tedious work in between. You can easily miss collectibles and then have to replay the whole chapter, cutscenes and all. For me, this creates a tension that sometimes leads to me not enjoying the level and disturbs the immersion.

Now it looks like it's more bad than good, but far from it. I'd love if there were more levels, especially the ending could have been more detailed. Like having to [spoiler]manually open the roof[/spoiler] would have made for a great sequence. Maybe more sidequests as well. But that's the difference between a triple A and an independent game.

Bottomline: if you don't hate cats - get the game. You will not be disappointed.

There appears to be a bug in this game, which on further research has been well known by the developers for the last couple of years but still hasn't been resolved. It's to do with the weapon 'Doc' gives you in chapter 2. As soon as you get it you can't progressed any further ... you're stuck where you are because the weapon can't be activated.
Edit: After restarting the chapter from scratch, I was able to proceed with the weapon working. However, I lost all my inventory that I had collected in the previous chapter. It took me quite a while to research and find the solution.
Otherwise, I am enjoying the game now. I am still at a loss why this issue has not been fixed after two years, it is the only blight on the game.

Easily in my top 5 favorite games of all time. The sound effects, graphics, movement, story, and atmosphere were incredibly consistent throughout. It was everything I could have ever asked for in a game - not to mention the obvious perk of playing as a cat! The pace was fantastic too, with a few puzzles here and there, and some moments of action and stealth, but nothing too complex. The best part was exploring and meeting new characters as well as the short side quests. A game with a lot of heart and one of the best gameplay experiences I've had in awhile.

It has such an interesting story to follow and recovering all the memories provides for such a different perspective on the rest of the story as you play. Albeit it is a bittersweet ending, I cannot rave enough about this game. If you're even on the verge of considering this game as an addition to your library...DO IT!
Love it. I still want to find my family though. Stray 2 would also be fun if they had a co op feel to it. Thanks for the great work guys.

(this review is a bit spoiler-y :) )

PROS:
- Plug-and-play: just sit down with your controller and play, no need to fiddle around with options.
- Superb technical realisation: QA have done their job right. I had no glitches in my playthrough.
- Graphically pleasing
- Cats. You can meow at people.
- Lore is fun to explore, the little jokes and cultural references make it funny.
- Simple control scheme makes it easy to pick up for beginners
- Creepy/eerie vibe really well done.
- It is very clear when you have to move and when you can explore freely
- Music syncs perfectly with moment-to-moment actions.
- Doing the 100% seems easy: I have not really tried and I found ~85% of memories.

CONS (nit-picking....):
- Sometimes it is not clear when you get out of a zone and you don't have time to finish the sidequests, you're already thrown in the next.
- Camera positioning could use a little work. It is very good, don't get me wrong but sometimes it is a little difficult to look around, especially when close to a wall.
- "Gamey" feeling near the end: first 1-2 chapters hooked me in, on the last 2-3 some puzzles reminded me I was playin a videogame: Big, convienient levers, (too) simple puzzles, etc.
- Inconsistent logic :
#1: Clementine lifts you over a fence but 5 min later she has to drive a truck near a similar fence to get you over it.
#2: Doc says "only this generator can power this light" and then fits this same light in a tiny robot the size of a cat's head.
- Unclear time frame : some robots say they have lived for 500 + years, some say they have 700+ years remaining. I get they live long. But it does not feel like it.

Overall a great game, might play it once again in a year or so, once I forget most of the puzzles.
Would recommend for beginners and pro gamers alike (a little rest is well earned). Just don't let children play this game alone as it can get very scary sometimes.

I loved every second of this game, it looks beautiful, it sounds beautiful, and I played the whole thing in one sitting. There's nothing difficult about it, but the experience and atmosphere are enough to keep you entertained, well worth the price.

this game is absolutely fantastic. the world is so interesting and fun to explore, seeing this world in the eyes of a cat was so interesting, being able to mess with npc's (sorry about dropping the bucket of paint) and being able to do simple cat things like scratch, meow, drink water, sleep etc. was fun. the game at its core is pretty short, around 5 hours or so if you just do the story, but if you wanna 100% it youll get more value out of it, which i recommend doing because again, the world and its story was just so good. for a game having a mc that just meows, it will still tug on your heart strings and make you emotional. which mainly comes from finishing EVERYTHING the game has to offer so you can get dialog from specific characters. i highly recommend everyone tries this game out because its worth every dollar and every minute.

Stray is a great little puzzle game that has an awesome cyber-punk atmosphere

A simple but creative little adventure game with a predictable but nice story.  Didn't know it was sci-fi going in=) Wish they played a little more off cat/feline senses, and more varied actions, but still enjoyable for what it was.  However, NO WAY the price should be $30 for around 6 hrs.  Glad I bought it on sale, but $20 MAX for something so short and independent.  And looking at the achievements its amazing how few actually finish?  Wild.
Great game!  Good puzzles that aren't so difficult as to be hindrance to enjoyment.

Very relaxed and satisfying game to play, exceeded expectations.

Can be taken slow or quick, many explorable places throughout the different chapters and achievements are fairly simple, apart from a few slightly annoying ones.

Only downside is that it is relatively short, taking about 8 hours to fully complete including all achievements.

Hopeful for a Stray 2 sequel in the future.
i like cats

When I bought this game, I was expecting a calm, cute little cat adventure. What I got instead was an amazing, intense, heart-wrenching experience that truly changed the way I perceive the world around me. This game is so much more than a cute little cat game. It's a reflection of humanity's present and future. It's about fighting oppressive power structures for the good of society. It's anti-police state, anti-capitalist greed, and pro-community building.

Also you can get an achievement for meowing a hundred times.

cons:
 - has some progression-blocking bugs
 - doesn't run very well on m1 macs

pros:
 - meow
can't ask for much more than cats and a good story (so far), excited to see how it ends!

Absolutely! I just finished my first run of the game and got a big chunk of the achievements complete, going to do some clean ups to get the 100% now. Great story!

Stray is excellent. The concept and world that has been created is fascinating, and whilst the gameplay is not the most challenging, it was rewarding to discover the story and the world behind the game, which was deeper and more emotive than I expected. I thought it would be a fun, lighthearted game solving puzzles as a cat, and was hit with a heartfelt story about pets, humanity, and AI.

The length of the game does leave something to be desired - not so much the story, it's compact and well-told, but there could be more to explore, as whilst there are some collectables it does feel like a slight missed opportunity not to be able to see more of the intriguing world that's been created.

Achievements are fun and don't feel like chores - I'm just not sure how much replay value it has because there is only one linear way to play it, which links back to the limited exploration, and there's an achievement to beat it in under two hours which speaks to the amount you can actually do. Overall I would recommend the game, perhaps not for the full price if you are unsure, but if you get it on sale you can finish it in a long afternoon and thoroughly enjoy the experience.

Really good game, if you don't have anxiety, this game will give it to you, lmao! So many heartstring-pulling moments, and so many nerve-wracking obstacles. If you thought this was just a cute game (like me) you will learn in awe, while exploring an amazing world and meeting new 'people'!

Stray is a mesmerizing journey through a beautifully crafted cybercity where you take on the role of a stray cat navigating its mysterious alleys and rooftops. The game's immersive atmosphere and unique concept immediately draw you in, making it a standout experience in the gaming world.

From the moment you start playing, you're captivated by the stunning visuals and the attention to detail in the world-building. The gameplay mechanics, such as parkour-style movement and interacting with the environment as a feline, are incredibly innovative and add depth to the overall immersion.

However, one aspect that might not resonate with everyone is the choice of the cat's appearance. Some players might have preferences for different types or colors of cats, and the specific choice of a ranga cat might not align with their personal tastes.

Nonetheless, despite personal preferences, the game's brilliance shines through. Its storytelling, unique gameplay, and the sheer joy of exploring the world from a cat's perspective outweigh any minor concerns about the cat's appearance. Stray is a masterpiece that captures the essence of adventure and wonder, offering an unforgettable gaming experience.

Captivating within the first 30 seconds with its cute and lifelike portrayal of a cat... within a beautifully rendered world you can explore. Cat mechanics needed to succeed. Negatives: the run-like-hell-or-get-eaten segments (and there are more than one) pulled me out of the game. They belong more in a horror scenario. Some maps had bad camera controls, essentially restricting the player to one view. Short though. I finished in a few hours, missing only two "secrets". So I would recommend on sale.

It's a great game, a captivating and engaging story, linear gameplay and really funny moments (tripping robots and annoying them is fun).

It's actually the first game that motivated me to get all the achievements just to discover everything possible about the story.

After pushing through a somewhat lackluster and overly casual beginning, I was eventually met with an alluring narrative that sucked me into two long play sessions to complete this game (4-5 hours in total). 

In my opinion, most video games do not have compelling stories or characters and I find it harder and harder immerse my self in video games because of this. That is why I was thrown off to find that I was unable to put my controller down when playing Stray. Every objective I did just pulled me further into the plot, and I found my self emotionally connected to what I was doing, wanting to help the characters by completing every little puzzle or action.

The world of Stray is immaculate, fully lived in. If there was another game made around the same exact map, I would be more than satisfied to roam the city again.

Now some folks may find the gameplay lackluster, as it is mostly casual, but I think it's appropriate for this sort of storytelling. Not only is it fitting, but they do provide more variety of game play as you progress, keeping things from going stale.

As someone is finding it trickier finding games that speak to me, at this stage in my life, I think this is the sort of game I can see me playing more of: short, strong narrative, and with great attention to visual details.

Normally I play games like War Thunder or Ready or Not, but lately I actually want to unwind and relax playing a game instead of getting more stressed out. This game scratches that itch completely. I love cats so this aspect of the game already is a huge plus. The storytelling is amazing. The worldbuilding is amazing. The puzzles are just difficult enough to be fun but not too difficult to leave you guessing or even worse, googling the walkthroughs for a specific part. I died a couple of times, but not too much to leave you frustrated. The robots in the game are as cute as the cat itself. They are borderline goofy but nontheless relatable. Even if you are the thoughest kind of person, this game will still melt your hearth. 10/10

Stray is perfect game. Personally I can't find anything I disliked.
Story is interesting. City is immersive. Gameplay is exciting and intuitive.
Cat animations are very well detailed. There can be seen some flaws, but it's pretty rare occurrence.

The only thing maybe can be considered as disliked is game longevity. I hope this game would be a bit longer. Average time to complete this game is 4-5 hours.

There also some kind of high fps physics bug and your cat can be set flying (rarely, in 1-2 places) if fps is not locked on 60. Looks funny tho. Just know that you need to turn on v-sync/lock fps for a moment If you are stuck. Checkpoint is right there so this bug is not a major problem.

Very good.  Surprisingly complicated story told through the eyes of a cat as smart as a 10 year old kid trying their best.  Game isn't long (perhaps 20 hours, 30 if you search diligently for optional things) and leaves you wanting more.  Could have done with the ending animation showing more of what happens to the enemies.  Game is good at making you hate the enemies.

Rebind the key related to shaking off the enemy so that one press does the job instead of you requiring repeated shaking.  Without that I found it too difficult and frustrating.

Pros: Good graphics, good story well told, no crashes or freezes.
Cons: Autosaves can be quite far apart.  Maps feel a little claustrophobic if you have to spend a long time in one trying to figure out what to do next.  Short, but I still feel I got value for money.

Despite a wordless narrative, Stray's charm shines through in the cat's lovable expressions and interactions with the cybernetic environment. The game's visuals are a delightful spectacle, featuring an endearing feline protagonist exploring a neon-lit city with playful curiosity. The game seamlessly blends technology and nature, creating a whimsical world where cuteness meets cyberpunk. 

Gameplay mechanics are user-friendly, inviting players to enjoy guiding their adorable companion through the city's wonders. Stray is not just a game; it's a heartwarming experience that captures the essence of charm, making it a must-play for those seeking a delightful and cute gaming adventure.

The high price tag may be a consideration for some, given the game's relatively short duration.

"Stray" is a mesmerizing journey that immerses players in a visually stunning cyberpunk world where you navigate the bustling streets as a stray cat equipped with a tiny backpack. The game's unique perspective offers a fresh take on exploration and puzzle-solving, as you uncover the secrets of a futuristic city filled with robots.

Despite its brevity, "Stray" manages to deliver a memorable and enchanting experience. The attention to detail in the cybernetic cityscape, coupled with the endearing animations of our feline protagonist, creates an atmospheric adventure that resonates. The game's short duration doesn't diminish its impact; instead, it leaves you yearning for more, showcasing the potential for concise yet captivating gaming experiences. "Stray" is a delightful and visually arresting odyssey, even if it's over too soon.

I wanted to love this game, instead, I find it alternating between (what for me is) perfection and sheer misery.

I must applaud the developers for choosing easy kitty-leaping over tricky timed, pixel perfect jumps. I appreciate the excellent level design and the opportunities it provides for exploration. The character interactions, and the story (at least as much as I've been able to experience_I'm currently up to "Dead End") are very good if not great. The feline behaviors are spot-on. With so much going for it, why can I not recommend Stray?

Given the thoughtfulness and consideration for the player's experience clearly in evidence in all other aspects, I'm baffled as to why they couldn't also at least provide a variety of difficulty settings for the head crabs, er, I mean zurks,. I get that some folks enjoy dexterity/reflex challenges.  But as it is, I absolutely dread and detest the zurk levels. I derive zero sense of satisfaction/accomplishment for (finally) getting past them. Watching the kitty succumb time-after-time to the zurk hordes is horrifying (yes, I know there is a setting to disable seeing the cat's death--but we still all _know_ what happens). 

Call me crazy, but I do believe that one should look forward to one's next gaming session. With Stray my feeling is more akin to dread than pleasurable anticipation. Knowing that in order to progress in the game I must first get past the next zurk level is a HUGE disincentive to play. That I'm writing a review rather than playing ought to speak volumes.

Is this a game _you._ would enjoy? I don't know. But, I would not recommend it if your play-style preferences align with my own. I truly hope the devs read this review and respond by adding an option for slower, less aggressive zurks.

[As a point of reference, the astute among you will note the reference to head crabs. I had fun playing _Black Mesa_ at the "normal" difficulty level.  Yeah, there were some levels I had to restart a couple time. Compared to Stray, BM was a cakewalk.]

3 problems that keep this from being practically perfect:
1. I know it shouldn't matter, but like, why is the cat so smart? Like of course it's just a game blah blah blah, but I just feel like with other stuff being relatively grounded it's weird to me that the cat is intelligent enough to understand B-12 and know what to do and stuff.
2. The cats hit uncanny valley fairly often. I know it's hard to get that stuff right, but when the cat is the main character it's really important to nail it.
3. The biggest one to me, a lot of the meowing sounds sound awful, and they vary so wildly that a lot of them don't even sound like the same cat. I'm not sure if it's some procedural or AI thing, but that kind of stuff took me out of it

Other than those, it's a great little game. A bit expensive at full price, but if you want to 100% you'll get your time's worth. Absolutely worth it on sale.

I like the animations and how cute the cat is but honestly the game was really boring. I think its a very experimental game but definitely overrated, I would just get bored after like 30 minutes of playing it each time. Not only that but it's basically just puzzle solving, and the instructions are very unclear at times. The game takes around 4 hours to beat and the lore goes from good to dead with the NPCs. The game hypes up the lore at the start and then when you beat it, you realize it didn't really mean that much. The fact that you can accidentally beat this game on day 1 because the game hypes it up to be this long interesting story, recovering memories and escaping the city just for it to be done in a flash. The ending is also very dry and makes you just say to yourself "oh okay, its over?". The main reason I do not recommend it is because its $30 when it should be a $15-$20 game. If it was in that price range I would honestly be fine with the short and dry story. I'd recommend watching a YouTube video of the game unless you really want it.

I had been debating on getting this game for a while. I had heard various reviews from people, most of which had been positive. One of my concerns was that it would be a 'childish' game. Needless to say, I decided to take the plunge. The story of the game is just...wow. I had expected a light-hearted story about cats and robots (a pretty cool combination to begin with) and left with questions about humanity and society itself. The pure depth of this game is within the top compared to other games that I have played, and the game left me feeling a variety of emotions at the end.
     Another concern that I had was the length of the game. I was worried that it would be too short, especially after seeing people say it was only 5 hours. One of the best aspects of the game is that it can be as long or as short as you want it to be. If you insist on exploring every nook and cranny like me, you could easily reach the 16 hours that I had for my first playthrough. This is not to even mention the additional time that collecting achievements can grant you. When speedrunning the game afterwards, I was amazed at how areas that had taken me multiple days to complete could be finished in a mere 20 minutes.
     It was when going achievement hunting that I noticed the optional difficulty of the game. The game has only one difficulty setting but even that is unlikely to present frustration for the average player. At the same time, however, some skill is definitely needed in certain areas. I found that the game offered a nice balance between skill and story. The strategy sections did not occupy too much of the game, but they also felt intentional. Achievement hunting is a whole other beast. There were times when I felt real frustration as well as spent time planning my next move. I really enjoyed this aspect of the game, especially after having finished the game already. It honestly felt like a whole new game, and I imagine self-made challenges could increase the play time exponentially.
     One of the biggest selling points (for me at least) was that the protagonist was a cat. I can assure you that the developers fully utilized this gameplay choice. I was worried that the fact that you are a literal cat would be forgotten later in the game but every step of the way you see how being a cat both influences gameplay mechanics (get ready to get into some mischief), as well as the story at large.
     The game ran well on my non-gaming computer that I used for school, though I did have to turn the graphics down. Ran on a gaming PC, the graphics look stunning. They are obviously not as nice on lower settings, but I was still able to appreciate the beauty of it all.
     In conclusion, if you are interested in this game, I highly encourage you to at least give it a try. I imagine that within the first two hours you will be hooked. I encourage you to really enjoy the story your first playthrough and explore all that you can. Finally, allow yourself to look beyond the surface of this game and read into the analogies. You might just find yourself changed by the end of it.

Story is incredible, super immersive and honestly really emotional. It isn't a long game, I completed it in one sitting however I did miss some things and there are little side quests you can do so it's definitely replayable. 
The game has a disclaimer when you first open it saying that it is best played with a controller. I didn't have my controller handy so I played with keyboard and mouse.  You can definitely tell a controller was the intended mode of play, because some of the default keybindings are a little wild and make the game pretty difficult at times, but I played around and rebound some keys and that did the trick. Setting is beautiful, your character is adorable, you make some really sweet lil robot friends along the way, all in all this is the best game I have purchased and played in a while, and I highly recommend it. IF YOU HAVE A MAC, DO NOT BUY!!! 

After waiting excitedly for months for the game to be released on Mac, I was beyond disappointed to realize that the game is unplayable on Mac systems. Besides the game being really laggy and the game mechanics being nearly impossible to navigate on a PC, I cannot play the game for more than two minutes at a time now without it crashing. After having to restart the Dead End chapter due to a bug that many other users reported having, I was relieved when I was able to progress beyond the previous point I was stuck at. However, that relief was short lived as all of my inventory and side quest progress was effectively erased. Besides that, the game started crashing every few minutes to the point where I have spent nearly 3 hours trying to restart my computer/ steam/ stray/ tried every suggestion online to fix the issue. Nothing works. I have now given up and come to the conclusion that the game is beyond hope and unplayable. Incredibly disappointing as I was really enjoying the game play and have only come across a complete lack of regard or interest from Annapurna in fixing the bug. Save your money and your expectations.

Eh. This game has a serious direction problem, both artistically and in terms of gameplay. It feels more like a pastiche of ideas than a cohesive whole. Systems come and go without ever finding much focus, and by endgame you are playing a stealth platformer. The art incorporates a lot of grotesque elements that serve no purpose, which seem to be there just for shock value, but ultimately break away completely from the aesthetic that seems to be proposed by the game. It's an okay experience, but not really commensurate with the hype created around it.

GAI emotion-transceiving-ready implementation of a computer game. Well done!

Other than that, we have an interesting story and environment with the clashing of purpose and randomness, you are bound to get, if you got the planet wrong and are forced underground with the remainders of your entire civilization. In the end you will be rescued by a few nerds, scientists, a cat, and a lot of luck. Well, or you did not actually get rescued, but some memory of ancient times has been preserved in the end, and the cat is free to go outside. So what's the news?

Some puzzles, moving like a cat, no stealth though, no hunting, some running away in arcade-like frenzy scenery, some aspects could have used more options or some other variations, and some things could have been elaborated, but all in all this has been one of the greatest expericences i have had with computer games so far. Not in terms of throwing hours on the table, but similar to platformers like "inside", you could get some experience out of playing this, and it might stand out somehow. I found it entertaining and overall pleasing, visuals, sound, story, haptics, what not.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handâ€”the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedâ€”the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Great game. The tasks are balanced to be simple while simultaneously not giving specific direction and letting you figure it out. The pace of the story is great. The setting and design is top notch. Replayability remains to be seen.

Definitely recommended.

The aesthetics are very impressive, with great attention to detail. They did a very nice job with the cats design and behaviour. Many will find the game worth it just for this. Movements are not quite as free as I had hoped, so I can't just run around jumping for no reason. Similar is true for how the game and playability is structured; you can feel that your are just performing actions and solving puzzles in a set order, which can leave you feeling a little less engaged. The game is not a vast world, but they do a lot with what they created, which allows for a good ability to explore, and interact with your surroundings. I think the game was framed quite well to fit a cat-like view of the world, with the game seeming to be based more on thought, curiosity, and caution than action and violence. The game can be a little tricky at times for those playing without a game pad (on a related note, the game also had a glitch, so I was forced to download a mod and cheat in order to continue, but they may have fixed this). I felt like the end was ever so slightly anti-climactic, and could have both tied up a few loose ends and left room for revisiting previous areas without starting over. The re-playability factor is also unfortunately low. I would like to play again, and did try, but it seems too much of a repetition to enjoy (unless I waited a few years).

I decided to get the game despite internet's increasing unhealthy obsession with cats and the "slightly" biased 'overwhelmingly positive' reviews for the game.
As for the game-play I wished for more freedom controlling the cat. This could have been easily a movement focused game in the veins of [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/17410/Mirrors_Edge/]Mirrors Edge[/url]. Especially since cats are so agile. But almost never the movement flows and a lot of times traversal just feels downright clunky. Then there are the Zorg/tick/facehugger hybrid enemies. Why? At one point you start to fight them since you get a weapon. So everything that was special about a cat character is gone. 
Unfortunately also the story is pretty bland and the npcs aren't very memorable.
Visuals and atmosphere are spectacular most of the time. but then there's this meat-growth at some places in the game; and boy is it badly made. Yeah, I know graphics is not everything but these things are destroying the immersion so much. It really is the ugliest asset I've seen in any game. And i played [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1388770/Cruelty_Squad/]Cruelty Squad[/url].
I could only recommend this game if you're one of these weird cat fanatics or if you are willing to pay ~28â‚¬ for a admittedly gorgeous graphic demo.

If you want a game with an animal as the main character that got gameplay and worldbuilding right, check [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/417290/Ghost_of_a_Tale/]Ghost Of A Tale[/url] or [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/312520/Rain_World/]Rain World[/url].

This game does open world exploring right - small world with a lot of detail and very little wasted space. This game does not have much dynamic game play - you just do simple actions and button clicks as you explore and enjoy the world as a lovable cat. The story and lore are amazing and the use of sounds and lighting really gives you the feeling of a post apocalyptic, urbanised robot civilisation - its very immersive. The soundtrack and sound design really deserves high praise, easily a highlight for me this year.

In terms of achievements they are pretty standard. Some you obtain by playing the game while some you have to backtrack or go out of your way while playing the story. There are 3 in particular that can repulse players - one through unreasonable difficulty while the other 2 can be seen as time wastes. Still the game is short so they aren't the most frustrating to go for.

Overall, would give the game a 9/10. Definitely a unique experience when it comes to a story game.

But it's a small world, and there are set paths. This is just not my style of game. There are other games I have bought for the same price and have hundreds of hours spent because they were more replayable. Lesson learned.

Stray has been a comfort to me during the last few days of my cat's life and during the aftermath of her death. Stray's journey through the city back to the world above has allowed me to think of my sweet cat fondly, although through tears, remembering little things like how she jumped, how she meowed and how she purred. It's a beautiful game with a lot of heart and soul. I expect to return to it many times, to relax and to help me manage as I come to terms with my loss.

I never imagined I'd be saying this, but: I had to quit Stray because it was too hard. Most of the gameplay is about what you expect, you're a cute cat and you run around and jump on stuff and generally get up to cute cat mischief in a beautifully rendered environment. What few other reviewers seem to mention is that in between these chapters, there are numerous sections in which you're mobbed by a swarm of fast-moving, obnoxious little monsters that can kill you in seconds if you make even the slightest mistake. I died over and over again in these sections. The game has no difficulty or accessibility settings, so if your skills aren't up to the task then you're just going to end up frustrated. Maybe that's a fairly low skill level by many peoples' standards but if you would even remotely consider yourself a "casual gamer" then I'd suggest you pass on this one.

I recently dove into the enchanting world of Stray, and after a mesmerizing 10-hour gaming session, I can confidently say that it's a visually engaging and puzzle-packed delight. This game, unlike many others, doesn't confine you to rigid objectives but instead lets you roam freely, encouraging exploration and discovery at every turn.

Visually, this game is a feast for the eyes. The vibrant landscapes and whimsical characters create an immersive experience that kept me hooked from the get-go. The attention to detail in the game's design is evident, making every nook and cranny a potential source of surprise.

Now, let's talk about difficulty. While Stray isn't overwhelmingly challenging, it does have its moments of unexpected twists and turns. I must admit, I encountered the infamous No More Lives achievement (Die 9 times) within my first 5 hours of gameplay, thanks to those cunning Zurks! Those little rascals certainly know how to keep you on your toes.

If you're a fan of puzzle-oriented games and have a soft spot for feline companions, this game is tailor-made for you. The freedom to explore, the visually stunning world, and the delightful puzzles make it a standout choice for anyone seeking a charming and engaging gaming experience.

One of the best games to come out recently. Stray does an amazing job of making you feel like a cat. The world is huge and not built for you, but there's something to discover around every corner. Scale walls by jumping from ledge to ledge, destroy cables (and couches) by sharpening your claws, knock paint buckets off of shelves, nuzzle up against and befriend robots, meow, every action you take feels perfectly at home as something that a cat would do. The game is absolutely beautiful, even on the lowest graphics settings, but gameplay isn't neglected for graphics. The pacing is also wonderful. Something important is always happening, but the game doesn't overstay its welcome. If you like adventure games, cyberpunk/future aesthetics, robots, or cats, do yourself a favor and play this game.

Yes, its abit on the short side, I played for about 7 hours and 100% completed it, but it was such a blast finally playing it this weekend. Bought it on sale for â‚¬18, wich imo is still expensive for a 5-ish hour game, BUT trust me it was worth every penny just to experience this masterpiece. Its that hidden gem.

The graphics, artstyle, smoothness, music & gameplay are all TOP notch.
The developers really made this game with love and it has all the accurate little cat details in it.

I have my hopes on the future for more expansions or new games like this, this was simply amazing.

I put off getting the game or seeing anything to do with it for a rainy day. 

After getting a job at my local humane society working with the cats, I needed a distraction. While I love my job, we can't save everyone, it hurts the most when the ones you can't save are so small and helpless. So I finally let myself play Stray, and after witnessing what I have with my job, it made me appreciate the game all the more. We had an outbreak of panluek (kinda like the cat version of parvo) at my work, we lost some little ones. Watching them pass one by one whilst stuck in a cage left me deep in a dark pit, akin to what the cat fell into in the beginning. And again like I said before, we can't save them all, but being able to see the lucky ones break free of their cages; it makes our job worth it. I wish they could all find their own way home, but until they do I'll be their B12. Helping them along the way till they reach the outside.

Thank you for making such an amazing game/story <3
PS. I'll definitely be replaying it in my spare time to unlock all it's secrets, and maybe just to get up to some more kitty mischief.

I'm still a bit teary after finishing this beautiful game. Every megabite in stray is worth playing: Starting with a magnificent graphic over a catching and deeply atmospheric soundtrack that has its own character to the lovable protagonist - a cat! 
Critics complain the game is only unique because you are playing a cat. But they forget how unique a cat's perspective can be! And the fact that I can do SO MANY things that it does (knock over stacks of books, knock down cups, fall asleep on robots while purring, scratch sofas...) really show me that the developers have put their heart and soul into the game. 
The setting is very unique, too: Quite popular but I've rarely been able to feel the cyberpunk underground world as strongly as I did in Stray.
I don't have a single thing that I could complain and that speaks for itself. Thank you so much for this purr-fect experience!

This is a surprisingly touching story, where the (OBVIOUSLY ORANGE) kitty is both a necessary element of drama and sort of a comic relief for a heavy subject. The level design is incredibly well done, and the lighting is beyond perfect. The music and sounds are really fun, too. I truly don't see a reason not to get this game, especially if it's on sale. I loved every moment (even the ones I hated :)).

Stray, it's a puzzle platformer mixed with a point and click game. You are a cat, you are assisting yourself and a robot friend to get back to your children. 

Which you will have forgotten about completely after meeting the robot friend.

+ Graphics are quite pretty, if kind of standard UE5
+ Sound design is excellent, from great (and weird) music to little tippy taps of cat-paws on surfaces.
+ World-building is beautiful, with the robots being very cute.
+ Puzzles are fine. They mostly make sense. And the sneaking was fun.

- The jumping mechanic feels very unfluid and stilted to use. They should have looked at Mirror's Edge.
- Quite a lot of subtle and less subtle clipping issues.
- There are two different buttons for continuing/closing conversations. Why?!?
- You need a flashlight to see in low light. As a cat.
- I managed to soft-lock myself and had to replay a chapter.
- It's very easy to accidentally miss things and not be able to go back without replaying a whole chapter.

I'm still not entirely sure if it's worth the money. It was a nice enough experience, but it also feels a bit more polish would have been nice.

On a discount for sure. I'm not going to bother with all the achievements, though.

Even though this game has an overwhelmingly positive rating I must admit I'm a bit disappointed. This is a luke-warm recommendation because, frankly, the game is very eye pleasing and some of the characters are fun to watch. To trip the silly robots or watch them dance is fun for a while. At the discounted price I'd say go ahead and enjoy this pleasant little cat adventure. You'll find that the puzzles are of varied difficulty. My biggest drawback, however, is that the game is WAY too linear. Too many corridors where you feel like they haven't even tried to give the impression that you have a choice. I'm not suggesting open world, but at least a few more ways of solving the same puzzle as to make it feel like you're not just following along a scripted sequence.

Stray: Where Being a Cat is Harder Than it Looks. This game gives you the purr-fect excuse to roam a cyberpunk city as a savvy cat with a backpack. Forget nine lives; you'll need at least that many to navigate the urban jungle. From evading robots to mastering feline parkour, it's a catventure like no other. It's not just a game; it's a meowsterpiece. 

Warning: May cause sudden urges to nuzzle your own cat while questioning why they don't wear backpacks

I so much want to like this game but unfortunately the devs really messed it up. I do not get all the positive ratings here and can only imagine that they where posted after just playing the first hour or so. 

The gameplay is purely linear, there is not much skill involved since you can only jump to defined positions. The puzzles are not much of a challenge and quite boring. The story is meh. But where it only gets worse when you get to race those Zurk things. Racing them and blowing them up is not so much a question of skill but merely a matter of pure luck.
More often than not the camera pans to nowhere and you completely loose orientation which immediately means that you are dead. It takes an eternity to load the last checkpoint and you can wage another run. This is just so stupid and boring; it adds exatly nothing to the gameplay or atmosphere. 
There would have been so much potential in this game but it gets completely lost in those stupid Zurk runs and in the mediocre storyline.

A simple platforming puzzle game where you play as a cat that falls into a cluttered underground city populated by a robot society. The animations and graphics are great. The movements of the cat are spot on. I loved the story and really cared about what happened to the cat and the robot characters. 

The only complaint I have is about the difficulty  Much like a real cat you arent freely able to jump. Like a real cat you look before you leap. The cat leaps from spot to spot with precision and it is functionally impossible to mess it up. The puzzles are pretty easy as well. They don't require much thinking and often the solution to the problem is right next to it just a few feet away. The only times failure can happen is when you are facing enemies and even then avoidance is fairly easy.

  problematic at all, since it's very clear where you can and cannot jump on)
- I wish the game was a bit longer. First playthrough took under 7h, a speedrun took under 2h

Overall very enjoyable game, especially if you love cats and a dystopian setting.

It's not really that I've expected a different game, it's that it's less of a game and more a "narrative experience". Which is, in fact, laughable, because the story itself is boring. This game possess no redeeming qualities, expect for a cute cat. The game is really short, simplistic and, most of all, boring for its price. I beat it literally under 7 hours, and I wasn't rushing: I tried to clear every sidequest there was (there weren't much activities outside of the main plotline though). The gameplay is the main flaw of this game: it's just a bunch of simple mini-games, like really simple, plus platforming, which was programmed a specific way so you can only jump up and down in specific spots. Yes, you heard me right, this is literally a PRESS X TO WIN game, there's no free platfroming. Moreover, most of the time you just walk from point A to point B.
It's really one of those "flavour of the month" games which is only somewhat memorable because "haha funny cat is the main character".

Thanks to the excellent macOS port I finally had an opportunity to play this game through. The story is lovely but very short. Even though ending seems closed, yet I think that developers could expand this attractive universe with some soft sequel.

What regarding macOS port itself - that is fantastic utilisation of Apple Silicon architecture and Metal FX Upscaling technology, which manages to resolve image as good as DLSS does.

Stray is a puzzle, platformer, where you play as a cat who fell into a city and got separated from your friends. You, as the cat, explore through an entire city to find an exit to get back to your friends. All while finding robot friends, a little robot drone friend, and thousands of alien meatballs that attack you. It has polished movements, a good story, and great graphics. 

Would be better if it was 10$ not 30$... that's the only downside, buy when on sale.

The best game I have ever gotten by far. Hereâ€™s why.

1. Graphics. While there are certain things like partially floating on stairs the graphics is still amazing.
2. Storyline. The storyline is excellent and it makes you want more so letâ€™s say you are doing chores. What will you be thinking about? Stray. Going to school? STRAY. Playing stray? STRAY.
3. Movie like game. While it is just a video game it was made by a company that makes movies. You may know them from creating the movie nimona earlier this year so they know how to get the lighting PERFECTLY. 

The only downsides are:

1. Addiction. The game is so good you just want more.
2. Getting stuck. In certain areas even though to do parkour you just click a button, there are still parts where you run away from â€˜zurksâ€™. (Enemy robots.)
3. Ligma. You can get several side effects from this game including Ligma, Bing chills and getting tped through the backrooms into John cenas mouth into your mother and then back to where you were before. This can take hours or daysor months or even years. Most people call these comas but they shouldnâ€™t be called that. So yea bing chill.

nice game

So I did indeed read the reviews on this game before purchasing it and the ones everyone was "complaining" about had other people just stating that it was pretty much a skill issue. I can confirm that the main enemy "The Zurks" is the most Aids infested enemy that I have ever seen. I've been playing games for a long time included in those games is Elden Ring so I am no stranger to difficult game play I do understand that they are like the entire story of this game. However the chase events are in my opinion are very sloppy and poorly made the game does give a disclaimer on the title screen that the game is better on a controller which I will address in a second, The chase "mechanic" is completely broken essentially your not only expected to run from these creatures which come at you from in front in most cases so you'll have to run through a crowd of them which is pretty much a intsa-death and the only way to live through this encounter is to spam a certain button on your choice of controls, on keyboard and mouse it's the left alt key seeing how this game is literally on steam the majority of the players are going to play on keyboard and mouse, which this game was clearly not made for either way you have to not only run with WASD and the left shift but if you stop spamming the left alt key and these creatures get onto you (which they will) they will kill you in a matter of seconds, on top of all that its not a straight shot nor does the camera change its view point for you so you have to juggle all those key inputs and somehow use your mouse so you can see where your running to or just run into a crowd of these things that are literally placed around every corner. and in some areas of this game you also have to jump onto platforms to continue the area, so in some cases that's a minimum of 3 different keys and a mouse input and the majority of the chase events its 7 key inputs because you have to use WASD, left shift and left alt and a mouse input.

 *SPOILER AHEAD*




 The major tipping point for me to uninstall the game and request a refund wasn't even in the first zurks chase which was aggravating to say the least, it was the elevator spot where you have to wait for the worlds slowest elevator and run in circles yes i said CIRCLES and either pray that none of them hop on you at all or again try and juggle the key combos and use the mouse so you can see if the elevator is there and to make sure you don't get stuck on the abysmal terrain. Not to mention they are insanely fast and if one grabs you, you pretty much stop moving (you don't but your so slow that you might as well have) and then you get gang banged by about 40-50 of them. This game is a horrible port of a console game that was subpar at best to begin with based off the game play I experienced so far. The only upsides I experienced of this game was the visuals and the core cat mechanics I.E. climbing, meowing, scratching walls and carpets and knocking stuff off of shelves. There are as few clever mechanics that implement the core cat mechanics like in the beginning meowing will trigger lights that direct you in the direction your supposed to be heading which is completely dropped once you get B-12 which he just re-iterates what you where told in the first place which can be helpful if you put the game down for a while and come back. So I do NOT recommend that you purchase this game if you value your sanity or time even remotely I bought the game last night December 5th 2023 @ around 1-2 am I played an hour roughly before logging off and going to sleep and in that whole hour or so I dumped into the game I still had no idea what the plot of the story was I only started to get key info on what happened in the slums about 2 ish hours in which based off of other reviews and community threads a good portion of people didn't even get to experience. In other words don't buy this game if your expecting a chill play through as a cat and just learn about the story of the game because you'll have to get more sweaty that most COD lobbies this game was designed for try hards and the pretty much psycho cat people that defend this game like its the second coming of Jesus or some crap will tell you that you just suck at the game and its a skill issue, a good portion of the community are extremely toxic for this game being A LITERAL CAT SIMULATOR and gives off the impression that it is a sight seeing game with a good story but it is neither of those things.

Loved this game! What a fantastic concept overall, the cat as the main character in a dystopian world is perfect. If you're looking for a nice-looking, low key puzzler, this is a good one. Runs magnificently on the OLED Steam Deck. Iâ€™ve got it at 60FPS, all â€œhighâ€ settings. Super cute game, with just enough challenge and story. Love the semi-open world. LOVED IT!! started off meh, but builds and builds and builds!!!

I'm amazed at this game. The story and graphics are beautiful. The ending is meant to be hopeful, but due to certain circumstances, I find myself feeling a bit bittersweet (which is not a bad thing). I'm surprised at how attached I got to a lot of characters and areas we get introduced to. Usually, I have trouble forming connections in games, but by the end, I realized how it had me wrapped around its finger when everything got stripped away (I cried twice lol). The gameplay is super fun and isn't incredibly challenging. This might be a downside to certain people, but to me, it was a plus. The threats were effective, but not scary. This is another thing that I like since I didn't play this for a horror aspect. 

Overall, great game. I would love a second one exploring the outside area since I believe there's a lot of potential there. I also just want something that'll help heal my heavy heart.

A great game with good graphics, fun par core, and chase scene game play; I would recommend it. The story is really good, environments are very atmospheric, and the graphics brought it together. You also play as a cat so it gets a 10 out of 10 from me.

vERY GOOD
literally the game i would make if i could make a game thats how perfect it is
Fun and cute. Nice story. A few bugs and tedious controls here and there but nothing that overshadows the overall experience. Highly recommend.

I've played this together with my girlfriend and we both enjoyed it quite a lot. The characters are exeptionally lovely and the story is quite engaging. Everything just feels right about this game, not to forget the sometimes breathtaking graphics. The simple controls make it a delight to resume to play even after a long break, but it never feels too easy and some levels can be reasonably challenging. Thanks to the developers for this great gem of a game-experience!

For cat lovers, Stray is the ultimate game!  I have two rescues, so I immediately fell in love with this game.  So much to explore and get into, I am very much enjoying this experience.  Wishing for a little more control over kitty, but seeing how difficult the controls on other four legged animal games are (like Spirit of the North) I can live with it.  Super fun and recommended for cat lovers!
Great game - good story and graphics - great fun!

The graphics and interactions brought this game to life. They gave the robots their own meaning and hope even though they weren't human. I loved talking to them and doing the little objectives especially when i had to get the music sheets for the musician. I liked how you could rest the stray cat and just listen to the music and background sounds they were such a good vibe. I didn't really see anything i really disliked, although i was a little sad and felt a little different bu the end pf the game. 10/10 game.
Garfield would be proud of me
Love the game, Love the cat, Love the cat and the game. Very Nice, will recommend!
My one complaint is that there isn't MORE! Great story, great setting, and the puzzles and game mechanics were insanely fun.
This game is absolutely nothing without the cats and some people are fine with that. I was just expecting more and better puzzles that can't be solved by accident.
Cute
Super cute and very cool storyline.

i just finished my first play through and its such a pretty game, its fun that you can go on little side quests as well as the main game quest, the sci-fi cyber punk feel was amazingly put together and I dont know what im going to do with my life now that i finished it lol. i will definitely have to do another play through to try and get every achievement but overall its a pretty game, i think they should release a soundtrack for the bonus songs you can get the robot to play in i think the second chapter, i looked for one particular song for hours  because of how pretty it was but couldnt find it in the soundtrack or on youtube. 
 but overall amazing game and i absolutely love it.

I really love this game. It's not very long compared to most games and it's more linear than open world. There aren't a ton of side quests if that's what you're looking for, really only two (memories and scratches). Overall, this is a solid stealth game. I think it's a cool concept and I would recommend it. The graphics are solid, the story is interesting, the control is good, the puzzles aren't too challenging. I would give this game a strong 4.5/5.

You play as a cat, with the usual feline superpowers like knocking stuff off shelves, scratching doors until someone opens them for you and getting underfoot to the point of tripping people up. And it works. 

I'm not a big fan of the Zurks (picture as tick crossbred with a Headcrab), both running away and attacking is more frustrating than it should be. The sneaking around sentinels is much, much better and reminds me of Beyond Good And Evil. The puzzles are mostly fun, the story is pretty good and the world makes sense within its own rules. I do recommend.

Stray is the most amazing adventure game I have ever been given the opportunity to play. I've loved it since seeing its first trailer back in 2020, I couldn't wait to play it. my only fault with this game is that it ended and there hasn't been any extra content since its release in 2021. 

this game has such an amazing story that you can get really immersed in. I fell in love during the first cut scene and I kept falling in love every little step the little explorer took. for example, you can scratch your little claws on curtains, rugs and doors. you can find a place to sleep in every chapter. you can find little secrets throughout the story. YOU CAN MEOW!! 

I couldn't recommend a game any stronger. this game is purrfect for anyone with a love of cats, adventure, amazing graphics .. I can't even begin to explain how amazing the soundtrack is. please play it. it's worth every penny. it deserves so much more attention â™¡

The platforming is so fluid. Definitely recommend.

Stray is an absolute gem of a game!  As soon as I had seen trailers for it, I just knew it was going to be something special. You play as a cat and get to do the greatest of cat things; nap, nuzzle against people, knock things off tables/ledges and scratch to your hearts content! Little do you know just how much the game story will truly touch your heart. Your journey has meaning and although the game is somewhat short, it conveys everything it needs to in that time.  The soundtrack adds to the emotions you feel and overall, the game is truly a treasure to experience! I also really enjoyed having things to collect in the game! Collecting wasn't overwhelming or difficult but if you didn't explore things as you should, you might miss something!  I loved how you get to showcase your collection as well. :)  11/10 would play more games like this just to chill and enjoy more heartfelt animal journeys!
DUDE it was such a nice game. I loved it

My first review on Steam and I have to say, one of the best games which I played in my entire life. Apart from playing as a cat, which is absolutely great, the graphics, story timeline and general idea of game is one of most original I have seen. Hope more of such games will be created. If you are thinking about buying this game, It is 100% worth it!
nice game

Absolutely loved playing a cat!  I only wish to have the ability to choose how my cat looked in the game, but I was very, very pleased with how expressive the cat was in the game.  I hope to see more of the world created in this game.

This game is amazing. It has a good story that keeps you interested. The graphics are absolutely amazing, and the cat is adorable!

If you like cats, a good story and futuristic environments, get this game!

Give the game a go, and decide for yourself!

Also Momo is my favourite character lol.
I really just love being a silly cat going meow meow. This game is for the Warriors nerds!

Honestly, pretty damn fantastic. It's the kinda game to leave you a bit stuck on what to do when you finish it, as you can't stop thinking about it for a bit lol. The graphics are incredible and there's an impeccable attention to detail in the game. The story being told from a cats perspective is even more interesting and well done.
It's well optimised and my pc was quiet as a mouse running it, and i experienced next to no lag running it.
It's extremely fun to climb around and cause mayhem, and the game is almost completely void of bugs (i only encountered one small one through the whole game).
Each environment though overall similar has it's own completely unique and stunning environment and atmosphere. Setting the mood very well for each and every scene. Small scenes, atmospheres, difference in music, and other small details create diverse feels as you explore the game.
And of course, the game is a real emotional one (especially if your'e someone like me who cries at any mildly emotional animal-themed game anyway XD).
Honestly my only complaint and one that others may find a make or break on whether or not to get it: it's crazy short. Loved it, but I'm honestly disappointed that i paid 17 pounds (on sale) for a game that took me barely 6 hours to finish (and i took my time too). It's a short and sweet one with each scene looking and being great, but i was genuinely annoyed I had spent so much money on such a short game.
Even though I experienced motion sickness, I really enjoyed this cute story. As a cat person I had to play this game and I loved it!

A happy stray cat gets separated from his cat family by falling into a pit. Now he has to find a way back to the surface while exploring a dead cybercity with his new robo friend that he found on his journey.
Really short but solid game with a great final.
Plot is excellent. I can't stop myself crying at last. The music is wonderful and i love this. Not a loss to buy this game.

The fact that I have more achievements to obtain makes me look forward to enjoying this one again.

"Stray" is a delightful and visually captivating game that stands out for its unique premiseâ€”a stray cat navigating a futuristic world filled with intriguing puzzles. The undeniable charm of the game lies in the protagonist being a cute cat, adding a refreshing twist to the traditional adventure genre.

The puzzles in Stray are a highlight, offering a good balance between challenge and entertainment. The game keeps players engaged with a variety of puzzles that cleverly integrate the feline perspective. From navigating tight spaces to using the cat's agility to solve environmental challenges, the puzzles contribute significantly to the game's appeal.

While "Stray" isn't exactly a casual game, it has its moments of simplicity and accessibility. The controls are intuitive, allowing players to focus on the story and puzzles rather than grappling with complex mechanics. However, there are instances where the difficulty spikes, demanding a bit more concentration from players.

The storyline of "Stray" is undeniably interesting, weaving a tale of mystery and discovery. The narrative, however, leaves something to be desired, especially in the conclusion. While the story is refreshing and introduces new elements to the gaming landscape, the ending falls short of the expectations it builds throughout the game. It's not that the ending is bad, but it feels somewhat abrupt and leaves players wanting more closure.

The emotional resonance of the ending is commendable, but I couldn't shake the feeling that the potential for a more impactful conclusion was missed. I expected a bit more depth and development in the finale, considering the investment in the narrative up to that point.

"Stray" is a worthwhile purchase, particularly if you can snag it on sale. The game's unique concept, charming visuals, and engaging puzzles make it a standout title in the indie gaming scene. While it has its flaws, especially in the conclusion of the story, the overall experience is enjoyable enough to warrant a playthrough, especially for fans of puzzle-adventure games.

Such mixed feelings for this game... Don't get me wrong I loved the gameplay and atmosphere in this game but I definitely expected a little more. The ending especially left me feeling empty and with many questions. I was on the last chapter of the game and it didn't even know I was based on how the story was going... Also I hate how this cat never had a reunion with his family, his friend died, and how we didnt get to see the robots reactions for seeing the world being open and in their face essentially. I will say the game is stunning and I loved exploring the different parts of the cities and interacting with the other robot citizens. Would I recommend this? Maybe on sale honestly but full price not really worth it imo.

On the downside, the game was a little short and puzzles were a little too simple.

i followed this game from the very beginning, where it was announced as an obstacle game within a robotic world. simple but caught alot of attention! early videos of the demo are very hard to find - but i was happy to find the official game announced. at first, it was in the dark with no spoken word for a long time. i had faith in what distinct game design it was, and it came true. we need more games like these! but this one, very particular. a cat's pov? in an apocalyptic world? with robots? that transferred their well-beings into metal and tech, due to the downfall of mankind? which also, in turn gives me insight of animals that served as message-delivers in the past, or even, as saviours in the real world. Stray is one of those!

This game is stupidly beautiful, in all senses. Graphics are super good, but it's not only that: art direction, aesthetics, lightning, animations, architecture, dialogue, music... everything has a truckload of love put into it and the end result is just amazing.

Gameplay is simple, and it would certainly become repetitive if the game was longer. But the novelty of the cat's movement (which makes you to traverse the levels in very unique and imaginative ways) and the few mechanics that get introduced during the story are enough to keep you entertained until the end.

TLDR: It has a speedrun achievement but speedrunning it is 90% unskippable cutscenes and dialog skips.

Let me ellaborate:

This is a great game in many ways.  It's atmospheric and relaxing to play (for the most part); it has some adventure, platforming and puzzle elements, but it's mainly a walking simulator where the fun is in exploring the world and interacting with the characters.

With that comes it's one real downside though: it's short (I  spent about 11h on a completionist first-time playthrough where I got all of the collectibles and most of the achievements. The "main" storyline missions would  take 4-5h on a first play by my estimate, and can easily  be done in under 2 if you've already finished the game and want to rush for the achievement.

Speed- and other challenge runs would have been a great way to enhance replayability (and other games in the genre definitely pulled that off well), but the devs made sure you need to be a complete masochist to do those with Stray, since 90% of your time will be spent watching the same cutscenes over and over again.

Overall, I don't regret buying the game and I don't necessarily recommend you don't buy it. I've posted my review as thumbs down because as of now the game has a stellar rating and at a glance looks like it's going to have enjoyable post-game content, but it doesn't.

If you buy this, assume you will play it once, have a great time for up to 12h and then forget you own it.

Stray is a amazing cyberpunk themed game where you play as a cat in a neon-soaked world full of robots.
The game is part platformer, part traditional adventure game, and has a genuinely compelling story with some entertaining action along the way. The gameâ€™s world is bleak but full of history to learn and charming robot citizens to chat with.
The game runs fairly well on the Steam Deck LCD Gen 1.
Such a heart-warming and peaceful experience <3 i need more games like this in my life

A laid-back game with easy to learn controls and a unique story. If you enjoy adorable cats and robots (I mean, who doesn't?), as well as dystopian cyberpunk themes and environments, I would highly recommend checking out this title. It certainly appears to be made by a passionate creative team who had fun working on this.

The playthrough time is short and sweet, and I look forward to replaying this game--not just for missed collectibles and achievements, but for the story itself and any tidbits that I may have missed during my first run.

For anyone who might be new-ish to gaming (young or young at heart) that may be intimidated by overwhelming controls or menu interfaces, have limited time to invest, or regularly have an audience at home who enjoys watching the story unfold and solving puzzles with you, then Stray might be perfect for you. 

Not to mention, it's reasonably priced for what it is and a steal when it goes on sale. If purchasing for younger kids, I'm sure that they'll get a lot more playtime mileage (compared to an experienced teen/adult gamer) and enjoy exploring in the different settlements and cityscape levels.
meow

I am updating my review on this game after finishing the game. It is a must buy 10 out of 10. I can only say positives about this game. The story, graphics, art work, game play and puzzles are amazing. Truly a must have!

As someone who is very much a chicken that is scared of a lot, I feel like I should warn other people that there ARE some very scary elements of this game. That said, they don't come up often at all and didn't at all detract from how amazing this game was.

I laughed, I screamed, I cried - Stray is such an amazing adventure game and tells the story that it has SO WELL. It's a very singular experience that I've never gotten from another game and I can't recommend it enough.

I picked this u[ and played it for 105 minutes, couldn't figure out why i was feeling nauseous. The game itself is great, the storyline keeps you reeled in, but even after disabling motion blur and trying to sit closer and father away from the screen I noticed it was giving me perpetual motion sickness, like really bad. I'm no stranger to games like these with unconventional camera angles and movement but it seems that the devs still have some work to do with movement characteristics, because when I turned to reddit, I found I am not the only one who is affected. I wish i could recommend such a good game but the sickness its caused me steers me the other way.

What a fantastically fun little game here. Highly recommend!

This is actually my first Steam review ever. Stray is an insanely beautiful game with stunning graphics and a lot of loving details. You will find yourself standing around looking at your surroundings more than once. On top of that, the animations (and their little details, such as Stray hesitating a bit like a real cat before jumping to great heights) have been done really well. The story is touching and nicely told. The game could be a little longer - I now have so many questions about the universe that I want to play it again right away! I am really hoping for a Stray 2 <3 And of course, all cat lovers: go for it! You can really do a lot of cat things and behaviours throughout the game, and as I said, it is beautifully animated.

It looks nice and you get to do a few cat things, but playing the game wasn't all that much fun. The jumping is a little finicky, the enemies were more annoying than challenging, and the "search and find" quests are tedious. The environment is also a bit too contrived to guide you where to go (and where not to go), which made the experience feel unpolished.
The only part of the game that felt worth playing is [spoiler]the first 5 minutes[/spoiler].

Overall, I'd give the game a 6 or 7 out of 10. The [i]idea[/i] of playing as a cat in a dystopian cyber punk world is the best part of the game.

I just finished the game right before writing this and I have to say that you need to get this game. Its not just a game about a cat like I first thought, its a beautiful story of sacrifice, adventure, family, and even corruption for some reason. At the end of this game, I just thought to myself, "It's so sad that I have to leave all these people." They are just robots, but I love them all. I cried because I knew what was going to happen to them, and what had already happened, and I just wanted to hold on tight to every character in the game, and make sure that nothing bad ever happens to them. 
This game is amazing, and sad, but completely beautiful throughout the entire thing.

This game was even more awesome than what I was expecting!

The environments are visually stunning and very detailed, the characters are also pretty nice and interesting both visually and through their dialogue/backstory. There are both insightful and funny quotes told by characters to keep you entertained. 

The cat feels real, both by his gait, little moves and the action you can do with him.

The whole story of the game is creative and original, without having peeked at any trailers before hand, because I wanted to keep the surprise, I was indeed very surprised with how the story went. That's not exactly how I pictured a story about a stray cat to goes. I was very pleased with how it turned out!

The controls are easy to learn and the mechanics to jump from platform to platform is clumsy proof, you can't fall down by accident, so you can focus on solving the puzzle or escaping the enemy without any worry about missing a move because of a lack of dexterity. Which was much appreciated.

The only cons I found in this game is that once you finish a section, you can't go back to an ulterior savepoint, you can only restart a whole chapter, so if you miss a side quest and realize it only after completing the main one, you can't really go back a little to do it, you have to redo a pretty big chunk of the story. But it's only a minor irritant, I will probably replay the whole thing again just for fun anyways, so no big deal!
