Stray is an absolute gem in the world of video games. From the moment I started playing, I was captivated by its unique premise and stunning visuals. The game's protagonist, a stray cat navigating a futuristic city inhabited by robots, provides a fresh and immersive perspective.

The attention to detail in Stray is commendable; every alleyway, rooftop, and hidden corner is meticulously crafted, making the city feel alive and filled with secrets waiting to be uncovered. The gameplay mechanics, centered around a cat's abilities, are both intuitive and enjoyable, offering a fresh take on exploration and puzzle-solving.

The narrative of Stray is beautifully woven, gradually revealing the mysteries of the city and its inhabitants. The emotional connection between the cat and the player is palpable, as you embark on a quest to reunite with your family. The game's soundtrack complements the experience perfectly, enhancing the atmosphere and emotions throughout the journey.

Stray offers a mesmerizing escape into a futuristic world, combining breathtaking visuals, a touching story, and innovative gameplay. It's a testament to the artistic potential of video games, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a captivating and unique gaming experience. Stray is a masterpiece that deserves to be celebrated and cherished by gamers of all kinds.

Absolutely brilliant. It's one of those games that makes you rethink your idea of what a computer game is and what it should do. I don't even *like* adventure games that much; the last time I had fun playing something that had no blood and gore was when I played Monkey Island III. Stray is one of those games that fans of any genre will like.

This game is a lot to take in. It isn't a short game, but you get so into it that it might feel short. The story isn't anything new, but the storytelling in this game is phenomenal. To be able to take an idea that has been passed around and turn it into something genuinely amazing and unique is very awesome of the developers. The character design all the way to the sound design, everything is insanely amazing and it all works extremely well together. These developers did not miss a single detail, the game wraps you around it's finger and you feel like you are really there while playing it. That's how I felt anyways, it was amazing. I nearly cried at the end, so watch out to those who get too attached like me. The game ending is left a bit open-ended, however that is probably because they are currently making a Stray 2 already (with a dog). Hopefully, I don't mean to hypothesize, we will be able to get the closure everyone is wanting.

But it's just so well-polished and smooth, it's a joy to navigate through the world. It makes you *feel* for the characters you meet, and the universe you're stuck in.

It took me about 4 hours, and that feels just right. I generally find this kind of game to be boring and repetitive, and this was neither. A real hidden gem.

If you're unsure, buy it on sale. This Stray is worth your time.

What a great experience! Beautiful game. I personally love the GITS/Cyberpunk aesthetic (combined with a bit of Hayao Miyazaki I guess?). And it isn't just a surface level aesthetic, like some AAA titles do, the themes the game presents fit the setting very well. The story is really well done, as are the characters. And it's all shown from the perspective of a very curious, smart, and cute little cat!

The gameplay is like a platformer meeting a simple adventure game. It's very easy to pick up and learn and fun to play. Though some achievements (if you're the type that cares) will require a few restarts.

And that's it, what are you waiting for? Get the game. It's like half the price of most AAA games and has way more value and memorable moments than any of those. AND YOU CONTROL A CAT THAT DOES CAT THINGS!
It's a really cute game and the quality is amazing.

Rare games like these remind me of what games can actually be. They don't just get you to do random things; here, there's a story, not just a cute kitty game. It makes you empathize, it gets you to feel emotions, and it makes you feel like there's a purpose in the specific story here. I loved the unique parkour element since we are so used to a human view, that seeing it from a feline perspective was amazing. You could tell tell the team really loved cats! I hope there's a sequel for the poor fella though, give him a happy ending :c. One comment, I'd appreciate a map or an objective list because I'd have to refer to online resources just to find what I'm supposed to be doing for this chapter. I guess, to be fair, why would a cat bother with a map when it can roam around freely LOL but maybe its drone companion could have helped with organizing. Speaking of the drone companion, the team was amazing in putting small details like (SPOILER) if we are separated, we cannot converse with other robots.

Just finished this game around 20 minutes ago, Keeping it spoiler free, but trust me when I say that the story in this game is GREAT. If you're looking for a straight up cat simulator, this probably isn't the game for you, but if you want a game with an incredibly well-written and engrossing story filled with great characters, deep lore, a smattering of puzzle-solving elements, and a bunch of cute stuff mixed in, all while playing through the eyes of a stray cat in a new and unfamiliar environment, then this is most definitely the game for you. I'm telling you, this game is WAY more than what it may seem like at first.

If that's not enough for you, the soundtrack and the visuals in this game are freaking amazing too. The art direction is just fantastic in this game, and in my opinion, it's one of the best-looking games I've ever played. On top of that, it's unique soundtrack just makes this game drip with atmosphere and ambiance the whole way through. Seriously, if you're on the fence about it (like I was at first), just get in and play the game. Like, really, go play it. I'm telling you, you're seriously missing out on an awesome experience if you choose to pass this game up. Don't make me come over there and force you to buy it! Stop reading this, click the buy button, click install, click launch (or double-click the desktop shortcut, whatever your preferred method of starting Steam games is), and play the game!

I was waiting for Stray game from BlueTwelve Studio developers since the very first announcements. Two of my favorite themes at once - cyberpunk and kittens. To be more exact, a cat is the main character of Stray. However, the game is not about the cat, although he is certainly the key figure of the whole interesting story.
From location to location we are gradually revealed the plot, which keeps us in suspense throughout the game. The adventure itself evokes a whole range of emotions - sadness, emotion, tension and laughter.
Walking on the roofs here is especially delightful. The protagonist climbs higher and higher, and we get breathtaking views of different parts of the city. An unusual city, the main inhabitants of which are robots.
The game turned out to be very "warm" also because the robots here are not clear and logically designed machines, but capable of feeling and experiencing emotions inherent in any person. In many of them, literally a couple of lines can reveal the character, it's cool! How our furry hero ended up here, and where all the people are, we will learn as we go through the game.
Some locations deserve to be desktop wallpapers. The atmosphere of the city abandoned by people, transferred perfectly.
The most that I liked is the music. I added every track to my playlist and sometimes listen to it.

Cute for about an hour or 2, then (for me) becomes a tedious old dodge-the-creatures-over-and-over. The game plays like it is French or Canadian or worse, French-Canadian...it just has a boring generic feel to it. Even the cat is generic and you cannot change that easily, which is pretty stupid IMO, like how could they miss the opportunity to let you change your cat color or fur type? Maybe I want a Black Siamese or a longhair Blue Persian? 
I just cannot finish this, dodging those creatures and pressing the one button to get them off, boring, but I can still recommend it. It is interesting. Would like to see more games told from unique perspectives even though I found this to be a boring dud made by Europeans. I was looking for something with more buttons to mash, I guess. In this game you hop but only to certain areas and you can "meow" and you can shrug off creatures, and that is it. 
Boring.

The game's great, but the problem is if we don't pass on or if we get stuck in a certain place, we wouldn't know what to do next unless we watch some walkthrough or read a forum about it. A cat with a map would indeed look odd, and perhaps the game devs intentionally dismissed the idea of having a map to make us stay in the game much longer without relying on shortcuts. But personally, a map would've been extremely helpful for this game!

with a bit of exploring you can beat the game in roughly 7 hours without a prev play-through, it's fun to play but i do recommend waiting until it costs about $10 or less. the game feels incredibly rushed and there's no real "boss" or "threat" and though it gives you a "weapon" it doesn't stay with you long.

Edit; I'm not saying its a bad game, I'm only saying I don't think it was worth all $20 or so I spent, and that was on sale, apparently you can beat it in under 2 hours it says, speed running? hmm maybe.

(Minor spoilers)
First the good stuff - the cat is really cute.  The other cats are really cute too. The little flying bot was cute, but well, enough about that. The transmogrified robot people is a very cool idea and the environment they live in is one of the most innovative game concepts I've seen. Some of the enemies were rather disturbing, especially since as a little cat I couldn't splat them.

Now the not so good stuff. Who ever heard of a game where you can't dodge, roll or otherwise avoid danger other than running away at a not very fast speed? You can't even jump wherever and whenever you want. My cat is smart enough to figure out where he wants to jump without anyone planning it for him so I'm not sure why this cat couldn't do that as well. The keyboard/mouse play is, let's say, challenging. I played with a PC controller for part of the game like whenever the camera got locked into dead-ahead-only mode for I have no idea why.

However, I will say it was worth the price of admission since A) I like cats, B) the cat was cute and C) it had it's fun moments during the few hours of riding the rails. All in all, I would buy it again and will buy the sequel the day it goes on sale.  But I still hope they make it work better for PC players and ramp up the game play dynamics.

D

Do you love cats? Did you ever want to roleplay as a cat but not be shamed for such a thought? Do you want to play as a cat and go on an adventure where a tiny robot becomes your ally and companion? If you answered yes to all the above, then give this game a shot. 

A short story but it was fun playing the game. I spent some time getting lost in some areas as I was not sure where to find everything but in the end I enjoyed this game more than I initially thought. Playing as a cat as athletic as Lebron James but also sneaking past enemies like in Hitman was pretty satisfying.

Pros:
-Short but cute game play
-You are a cat that can jump insanely high and have the zoomies at the same time
-Visuals are atmospheric and the music is great as well
-Core game play mechanics are simple yet satisfying

Cons:
-You can die in this game (someone call PETA on these bots) but you can respawn
-Graphics: My God, I had insane lag and low FPS when I first booted this game and started playing the early levels. Looks like this game is meant for higher end PC specs to run smoothly at higher settings (sorry potato pc users)
-Story didn't seem quite as complete.... hinting at Stray 2?? (please devs make a Stray 2)

Great art design, but the playability is just not there to let me finish the game : (

Nah, too safe and boring. The platforming isn't real, you can't even fall off which ruins that gameplay element because then there's no real meaning to it other than traversal with pressing X and looking where to jump onto next. They went too far with that in terms in trying to appeal to very, very casual "gamers", and yes, i guess there are a lot of those out there.  

The world itself is very nicely designed and the cat animations looks really great, but its ultimately its just linear "corridors" and some puzzles. 

Perhaps it doesn't deserve a negative but this game certainly doesn't deserve overwhelmingly positive either, maybe a 7/10.  

I'd absolutely play a game like this with proper danger and platforming, that would be fun. I also played this in VR btw (mod), that of course makes heights look more scary and it's nice to see everything in real-life scale, but it didn't really help it gameplay-wise, it still felt too safe.

where do i start. 

When I first embarked on my journey through the mesmerizing world of "Stray," I had no inkling of the profound impact it would have on my life. Little did I know that this game would be the catalyst for a shift in my perception of life, evoking emotions that I never thought a video game could. The game's ending was a tearful culmination of an experience that has indelibly altered my perspective on existence itself.

"Stray," developed by BlueTwelve Studio, plunges players into a meticulously crafted dystopian cyberpunk world where you assume the role of a lost cat navigating the bleak streets of a decaying metropolis inhabited solely by robots. From the outset, the game's atmosphere envelops you, immersing you in a hauntingly beautiful, post-human landscape that serves as the backdrop for your feline adventure.

The brilliance of "Stray" lies in its ability to weave an emotionally resonant narrative without a single word of dialogue. Through the eyes of our furry protagonist, we witness the loneliness, isolation, and fragility of existence in a world devoid of humanity. The game's masterful storytelling unfolds gradually, and each interaction with the enigmatic robots or environmental clues deepens the sense of melancholy and wonder.

As I progressed through the game, I found myself connecting with the cat's struggle for survival and longing for connection. The sense of vulnerability that permeates every moment was a stark reminder of our shared vulnerability in the real world, and this resonated deeply within me. "Stray" prompted me to reflect on the beauty and fragility of life itself, a theme that became increasingly poignant as the narrative approached its climax.

However, it was the game's ending that truly moved me to tears. Without giving away any spoilers, it suffices to say that the conclusion was both heart-wrenching and uplifting. "Stray" managed to deliver a message of hope and connection in the face of adversity, leaving me profoundly touched and emotionally raw. It was a testament to the power of storytelling and the impact that video games can have on our lives.

In the weeks that followed my completion of "Stray," I found myself pondering the game's themes and messages constantly. I began to view my own life through a different lens, appreciating the moments of connection and the beauty in everyday existence that I had previously taken for granted. "Stray" had opened my eyes to the importance of empathy, resilience, and the pursuit of meaning in an often tumultuous world.

In conclusion, "Stray" is not just a video game; it's an emotional odyssey that transcends the boundaries of the medium. Its hauntingly beautiful world, captivating narrative, and emotional depth have left an indelible mark on my soul. It reminded me that even in the darkest of times, there is light to be found, and that life's struggles are what make it all the more precious. "Stray" is a masterpiece that has changed my life, and I will forever carry its lessons and emotions with me.

It's a fairly boring walking simulator and that's kinda sad because this game had a ton of potential. 

It started off fairly strong but quickly fell apart and it almost felt like the developers wanted to do something more with the story but didn't know how or were too scared to pull it off. 

Spoilers ahead:

[spoiler] It really annoys me how depressing and hopeless this whole game is. It's supposed to be, or at least I thought it was supposed to be about hope for the future and finding your family, yet every single person you meet, you end up abandoning for next to no reason. Hell, I figured the whole point of the game was to get back to our cat family and the devs even bungled that. This game would have been an easy recommend, despite my other problems, had the devs just had the Stray reunite with his family. It could have been so easy.

My other problem with this game is the wasted potential. Our main companion throughout the whole game turns out to be the last human who uploaded his consciousness. But as you explore the game you are told that for some unknown reason, the robots all evolved to be more human over time, I thought it would have been REALLY cool if the entire human population of the dome uploaded themselves to the robots due to scarcity of supplies or y'know the virus that was hinted to be going around or were using them as some sort of surrogates while they remained in hyper-sleep or something but because it had happened so long ago, they all forgot. The ending of the game could have been us opening the dome and also solving the puzzle of where all the people went. Honestly I feel like this was originally part of the plot with how much foreshadowing there was. [/spoiler]

The story is interesting and the characters are unique. The gameplay is quite fun and engaging. The difficulty is a good medium of not too hard as to require a full session to complete a single task, but not too easy to feel like the whole thing is just handed over. It is a beautiful game as well.

[/h1] Beautiful cat game [/h1]
	Do you want to know how it is to be a cat in a post-apocalyptic cyberpunk world? In this game made by BlueTwelve Studio, we are a cat that got separated from our family and now needs to find a way home while trying to escape the dangers in every corner of a mysterious cyber city.
	I find the aesthetics of this game stunning, and it follows the traditional cyberpunks style. Consequently it has a lot of neon colors, raining places, and retro-futuristic tech. Additionally, the cat is cute as it should be, and there are places in the game where you can just relax and enjoy the view as a cat.
	The gameplay, where every game feels the necessity to be big, is small and well made. Moreover, everything in this game feels great to do, from walking to even just scratching random doors as a cat has a good feeling to it.
	For people that like cats and cyberpunk, I absolutely recommend this game. On the other hand, if you do not have a soul and hate cats, you should get treatment.

Graphics: 10/10! The lighting design in the game is really good, the retro / neon style is very vibrant and i like that. 
There are no optimization issues (at least on my system), which i appreciate a lot, since most of the recent games have been a total lackluster in optimization. Well done.
Sound: 7/10, I think the game could have more immersing ambient noises, especially in the midtown area. The soundtracks are subtle and they are fine, but nothing too spectacular.
Controls: 10/10! The controls in the game are very easy to use, especially on controller.
Gameplay & Story: 8/10, i think the game could've had a bit more deeper story and a relationship with the characters in the game, Especially with our drone friend.

Overall, this is one of the best recent games i've played in this year and i highly recommend it. Meow!

Are you SO excited to play as a cat that you will endure a mediocre story, and boring, repetitive gameplay to play as a cat and  leave a positive review? Then this is the game for you!

I'm not especially into platformers and this one is not even a very good one, generally you are using the right stick to look around and find things with an "X" which means you can press "X" to jump there. So it's more like "find the next thing to jump to" than, well, parkour. 

Every interaction with anything in the world has to be "translated" so the cat can understand it, which involves pushing the square button, waiting 3 seconds, pushing the square button again, and then finally when the last line of dialog/info is delivered you press the CIRCLE button. 

So, understand this game is going to be very, VERY simple puzzles, very easy platforming, a lot of "square, square, square, circle" interactions, and the occasional "run really fast and don't let those enemies touch you" sections. That's it.

Tonight (so technically the 15th), I wrapped up Stray, a cyberpunk post-apocalyptic game where you play as a cat. I won't go into spoilers but this was not what I expect basically at all. It's a relatively short game, taking me about 7.5 hours. I only earned 10 of the 24 achievements but I do feel like I explored and took my time.

Visually, this is a cool game and I like the overall concepts. I did run into a bugged mission that I had to look up because characters weren't where they were supposed to be. Otherwise, there were times when it was unclear what was expected of me but nothing too serious to be frustrating or annoying.

The Story was cool. I enjoyed the characters but I want more of an epilogue.

I played on Steam Deck and highly recommend adjusting the graphics settings. My standard settings were getting 60-90 minutes of play time but after adjustments to some recommendations, I was getting at least double that time if not more. It felt good to play on Steam Deck and it was a very positive experience.
Awesome cat simulator with astonishing feline physics.

Press B to meow.

It is a very charming game, except you have to play it. And sometimes, that gameplay is bad. Pointlessly bad, in an otherwise completely casual game. It is two experiences, and one of them is fantastic and almost worth recommending the game. 

The controls are too limited, it is too linear, and despite a very casual veneer it is a bit try-hard for no apparent reason. It isn't really a game that you ought to git gud at, but these moments of weird difficulty spike exist for very mysterious goals.

In the end, the gameplay is too poorly defined and inconsistent in tone. The writing is charming, the cat is fun when you can actually be cat like. I would like to see a sequel that addresses the many gameplay limitations and then if they want to make it hard give us difficulty settings. 6/10, so close.

Absolutely adored this game, and it will have a special place in my heart. One of the most compelling games I've played in a while (which I did not expect?). I enjoyed the larger story, which I think some people beef with, but how I see it is that this is ultimately NOT a cat-sim, it's a story-driven game and the story is beautiful, supported by great visuals.

A compelling story and possibly a reunion/part 2 possible but it is a very satisfying ending.
Great voice and meow acting

A Cat game, might think its just a niche game utilizing the cat factor to attract an audience but don't let that cat distract you, there is so much more to the game that meets the eye.

 As a game its not innovative, platformer and stealth with a bunch of interactive physics is all your gonna get, but the Narrative, Sound Design, and especially the details, animation included are amazing, since they went out of their way to get motion capture on cats.

 The Art Direction chosen and how lighting is utilized makes this game a sci-fi eye candy, neon lights, poverty, trash everywhere, brutalist architecture, now i am a little bias since i highly appreciate brutal city landscapes but all of those make for a memorable sight everywhere you look, the shaders/lighting is just my favorite part of the graphics, then again, Artstyle > Graphics.

The Story can be basic on the surface but if you just start scrutinizing and questioning things, you might find that this game potentially talks about a lot of things, with numerous messages able to be interpreted but i won't get into that, 

Its definitly worth its price even as a short game. Its not meant to be played, but it must be experienced and immersed into, the gameplay is challenging enough and the story and lore leave a lot of questions to be answered even after the end. This follows the kind of story you get from Journey or ABZU, though not as intensive in the mystery part of those game, Stray still answers a lot. So if you are into those kinds of games where you are told the story of a fallen civilization through an outside perspection with strong Art direction, visuals and a well written narrative then these three games are for you, Stray being the star in this review.

It had been a while since a game had captured my attention and interest so much, and it kept me glued to the gameplay for so long.(The game is kinda Short tho)
Stray is an absolute gem in the world of gaming, a very creative and inovative mechanics, and it's "purr-fectly" tailored for the new games generation. In this unique adventure, you step into the furry paws of a stray cat navigating a mesmerizing futuristic world teeming with robots. From the moment you start playing, you'll be whisked away into a beautifully crafted cyberpunk city that will leave you feline fantastic!

The game's attention to detail is simply astounding. The physics and mechanics are top-notch, providing a remarkably realistic portrayal of a cat's movements and behaviors. You can jump, run, drink water from a pond, Headbutt on characters to show affection (Just like a real cat), enter cardboard boxes and even meow to interact with your environment. It's a truly immersive and beautiful experience that allows you to see the world from a feline perspective.The camera angle is another thing, you feel you are a small creature in a big city I love this.

But what truly sets Stray apart is its captivating plot. It's an adventure that keeps you engaged from start to finish, unveiling mysteries and surprises as you go. And let's not forget the soundtrack â€“ it's a masterpiece in its own right. The beautiful and soothing music, combined with the strolling in Honk Kong like streets, creates a wonderful ambiance that immerses you in a delightful sensation, evoking a sense of tranquility and contentment.
Stray is a game that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming. It's an experience so immersive that, for a moment, you'll forget you're playing a video game. It's not just a game; it's a work of art. If you're looking for an unforgettable journey that combines stunning visuals, realistic cat ergonomics, and a captivating storyline, Stray is the cat's meow. Don't miss out on this one, fellow gamers â€“ it's a true masterpiece! ðŸ±ðŸŒŸ

It's been said a thousand times how cute, endearing, fun, and utterly amazing this game is, but repetition doesn't make it any less true. There isn't too much I can add that hasn't been purr-sistently emphasized before. Instead, I'd like to highlight something that doesn't receive the attention it truly deserves, but fellow players would certainly agree, this game is utterly unique, and all I can say is... !!FINALLY!!

In our era where most modern games tend to fall into the same old litter box of basic categories with a different story and texture pack change, Stray is a breath of fresh catnip. With a dedicated "meow" button that serves a real purr-pose, it stands out as a unique experience, and we need more of that feline freshness in the gaming world! This game is so versatile it could fit into multiple cat-egories, making it impossible to pin down.

Pros:
    Purr-fectly unique   
    A dedicated "meow" button.

Cons:
    You're not playing it right meow.

Cute game that's "kind of" worth investing some time in. It's clear that a majority of this game was focused on the world building artstyle and graphics because it's a really beautiful immersive world. The story is intriguing but far too much of a slow burn and the gameplay is really just okay, not too exciting. From an indie developer I would say this game is a total win and I would recommend it to anyone who needs a brief distraction.
Amazing.
Fun.

This is neither a challenging game or one that will truly test your brain but it was absolutely impactful all the same. I had been told many times to give it a try because it was "not what i would expect" but i did not listen. Now that i beat it i can only say the same thing to anyone else that thought the same as me. It is a very touching story with emotions in the vein of a Pixar movie (not to the same grandeur of effect but that is the style it is chasing) that, if you let it, can open the conversation about sentience in the same way a good, deep sci fi story can. Its choice to see a world through the eyes of a cat is also something that, before i played, seemed strange but now on the other end was a masterful choice that gives the narrative a beautifully alien context. My only words of warning are this, it is DEFINITELY a short game (my game clock says 10 hours but the play through was really only about 4 and a half) so if you are someone who needs 30 hours in their game to feel worth it, this is not for you. Otherwise just prepare to enjoy and step into a deeply interesting, engaging, and eclectic world that will for sure sit in my memories for a good long while.

[h1] disappointing and shallow... [/h1]

...no matter how pretty the game looks or how fun it is to play as a cat. 

And that truly is the only thing about this game that makes it stand out over other indie games (which I truly don't think it deserves.) It's very fun to play as a cat and some of the level designs are very clever, allowing you to do certain things because you're an agile little kitty. It's good stuff. But, honestly, half way through the game I forgot that I really was a cat, because you get to communicate with the other robots using your robot buddy. Other than the novelty, being a cat doesn't mean anything in this game. 

Also, the story is thin, relying on a fairly standard post-apocalyptic sci-fi narrative and world design that kind of tricked me into thinking I was loving the game at first, because it kept reminding me of other games that I really wanted to play that had more depth and a more original story.

This game suffers from making you feel like it's going to be 3-4 times the size and scope that it actually is. I think the world design and aesthetics contribute to that. It's pretty short, around 5-6 hours and not as full as it could be. It's definitely not worth $30. 

Part of the reason that the world feels small is because you don't get to know most of the characters deeply because they only say 1-2 lines total, some NPCs say the exact same thing, so it feels kind of hollow and doesn't feel like you're in a real city. Also, since you're a cat, you don't actually speak with anyone for the whole game. You play as a cat but feel like you're basically no one and there's no way to know who this cat is. Since I didn't know who I was, I didn't have any emotional connection to the one companion you're supposed to care about. It's a one-sided relationship. 

I don't hate this game. It's a fun little romp and I love being a cat. But it's a deeply forgettable game beyond that with a weak emotional core.

[h1]Short, Interesting Experience[/h1]

Similar in gameplay to an old-school point and click adventure, but done in a fantastically crafted 3D world. The feline mechanics are very well done and will make you feel the highs and lows the protagonist experiences. Other notables:
[list]
[*] Being able make progress but not trigger a save is horrible; I lost 15 minutes of progress due to a "teleporting back after any jump" bug
[*] Long stealth sections (e.g. [spoiler]the factory in Midtown[/spoiler]) makes you restart from the beginning on any failure
[*] It would be nice if you could sit anytime and if sleeping saved your progress
[/list]
Unless you really love the genre or want to play as a cat, I'd wait for sale.

A lovely casual game! I really enjoyed this game. It has a cute story, and sweet interactions with other characters. It's a short game, but the graphics is beautiful, the story is lovely, and the game mechanics are simple and chilled. Also, you can meow on demand whenever you like - very cute.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

I already finished this game and I must recommend it.

It has everything what I expected from it.
+ Linear interesting story (with quite lot side missions).
+ Really beautiful locations.
+ Control interface is made for consoles but it is definitely playable on mouse and keyboard.
+/- Open ending. There is happy end (what is probably expected). But is very open. I hope that there will be some DLC or whole new game which show to us how everything ends into details. But I don't feel robbed as some players in negative reviews.
+/- Zurks are quite easy to prevent. But if there is lot of them then there is possibility to die. And all Zurks in location are respawned. And that respawn of all Zurks is little bit annoying.
+/- Little bit short. If I didn't stuck in one location for 1.5 hour and have little strugglle with Zorks. I will finish it in 5 hours.

Buy it if you like good stories and cats. But in sale (as me). I don't think that it has value of 30$.

Such a fun play-through! It really reminded me of Tomb Raider (platforming) and Metal Gear Solid (sneaking) with a third-person POV of a cat. Many of the cat mechanics are just too cute and brought a smile to my face. I did encounter one or two camera issues, but they weren't anything to complain about. The game was an absolutely amazing experience. I played 99% of it on a Steam Deck as well, and I'm 100% happy I played this game. It's simple enough for almost anyone with thumbs to play and be entertained.

It has heart and soul. Sometimes it's a challenge, other times you can roam. Ultimately it's about relationships... light touch, but also dark themed. Difficult to play again because a few of the challenges are unnecessarily difficult, and much of the story writing is drawn out and heavy. It's a happy ending, but one time is good.

Honestly, as much as I wanted to like this game, it doesn't have much going for it. The story is bland and every single character is just about as 1 dimensional as it gets. I think this game fits more into the category of an 'experience' rather than an actual game, but it fails at that, as I don't feel I gained anything from the experience at all. 
The only positive I can give this game is the world design and graphics. Its a beautiful setting and one that really appeals to me in particular. However, I don't think these alone can make for a good experience with a game; there needs to be something else, be it gameplay, story, characters, etc. Without any of these I felt I lacked any motivation to continue. If you only want good graphics and atmosphere, this is for you, but don't expect the rest of the game to live up to that standard.

9/10 AMAZING GAME!!

Cute factor aside and the adorable character design and setting, this game is really special and unique. Playing from any small POV in a game can be very exciting because it is a foreign viewpoint; however, the cat being able to move around and explore small places in the city is awesome. The setting and design of the world/characters/homes/etc was phenominaly done and really pretty to look at. It felt like a well designed and pretty place to get lost in.

While the story was just okay and the difficulty was very easy, I appreciated this run through an underground world and interesting background. I would love to see more of this style, with just a bit more difficulty in puzzles.
